DIV1.P: A King and no King. Acted at the Globe, by his Maie∣sties Seruants.
Written by Francis Beamount, and Iohn Flecher.
AT LONDON Printed for Thomas Walkley, and are to bee sold at his shoppe at the Eagle and Childe in Brittans-Bursse. 1619.

DIV1.HEAD: TO THE RIGHT VVORSHIPFVLL, AND VVORTHIE Knight, Sir HENRIE NEVILL.
DIV1.P: I Present, or rather returne vnto your view, that which formerly hath beene receiued from you, hereby effecting what you did desire: To commend the worke in my vnlearned method, were rather to detract from it, then to giue it any luster. It sufficeth it hath your Worships ap∣probation and patronage, to the commendation of the Authors, and incouragement of their fur∣ther labours: and thus wholy committing my selfe and it to your Worships dispose I rest, euer readie to doe you seruice, not onely in the like, but in what J may.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: BEssus, the KING has made a fayre hand on't, has ended the warres at a blow, would my sword had a close basket hilt to hold wine, and the blade would make kniues, for we shall haue nothing but eating and drinking.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: We that are commanders shall doe well enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr.
SP.P: Faith Bes. such cōmanders as thou may, I had as liue set thee Perdue for a pudding yth darke, as Alexander the great.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: I loue these iests exceedingly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I thinke thou lou'st them better then quarrelling Besss, He say so much ythy behalfe, and yet thou art valiant enough vpon a retreate, I thinke thou wouldst kill any man that stopt thee, and thou couldst.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: But was not this a braue combate Mardonius?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Why, didst thou see't?

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: You stood with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I did so, but me thought thou wikst euery blowe they strake.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: Well, I beleeue there are better Souldiers then I, that neer saw two Princes fight in lists.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: By my troth I thinke so too Bessus, many a thousand, but crtenly all that are worse then thou aue eene as much.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: T was brauel done of our King.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Yes, if he had not ended the warres, I am glad thou darst talke of such dangerous businesses.

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.P: To take a Prince prisoner in the heart of his owne Countrey in single combate.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: See how thy bloud cruddles at this, I thinke thou wouldst be contented to be beaten in this passion.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: Shall I tell you trulie.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: I could willingly venter for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Vm, no venter neither good Bessus.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: Let me not lie, if I doe not thinke it is a brauer peece of seruice, then that me so fam'd for.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: VVhy art thou famd for any valour?

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: I fam'd, I, I warrant you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I am verie heartily glad on't. I haue beene with thee euer since thou cam'st ath' warres, and this is the first word that euer I heard on't, prethee who fames thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Bes
SP.P: The Christian world.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Tis heathenishly done of them, in my conscience thou deferu'st it not.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes
SP.P: Yes, I ha done good seruice.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I doe not know how thou maist waite of a man in's Chamber, or thy agilitie in shifting a trencher, but otherwise no seruice good Bessus.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: You saw me doe the seruice your selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Not so hastie sweet Bessus, where was it, is the place vanisht.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: At Bessus desperate redemption.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Bessus desperate redemption, wher's that.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: There where I redeemd the day, the place beares my name.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Prethee who christned it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: The Souldier:

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P:
If I were not a very meerely dispos'd man, what would become of thee: one that had but a graine of coller in the whole composition of his body would send thee of an arrand to the wormes, for putting thy name vpon that field: did not I beat thee there yth head, a'th troupes with a trun∣chion, because thou wouldst needs run away with thy com∣pany,
when we should charge the enemie.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: True, but I did not runne.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Right Bessus, I beat thee out on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: But came not I vp when the day was gone, and re∣deem'd all?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Thou knowst, and so doe I, thou mean'st to flie, and thy feare making thee mistake, thou ranst vpon the enemie, and a hot charge thou gau'st, as Ile doe thee right, thou art surious in running away, and I thinke we owe thy feare for our victorie. If I were the King, and were sure thou wouldst mistake alwayes, and runne away vppon the enemie, thou shouldst be Generall by this light.

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.P: Youle neuer leaue this till I fall foule.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: No more such words deare Bessus: for though I haue euer knowne thee a coward, and therefore durst neuer strike thee; yet if thou proceedst, I will allow thee valiant, and beate thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: Come, come, our King's a braue fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: He is so Bessus, I wonder how thou com'st to know it: But if thou wert a man of vnderstanding, I would tell thee he is vain-glorious, and humble, and angrie, and patient, and merrie, and dull, and ioyfull, and sorrowfull, in extreamities in an houre: Doe not thinke mee thy friend for this, for if I car'd who knew it, thou shouldst not heare it Bessus: here hee is with the prey in his foote.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Arbaces and Tigranes, with attendants.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Thy sadnesse (braue Tigranes) takes away
From my fall victorie; am I become
Of so small fame, that any man should grieue
When I oreceme him: They that plac't me here,
Intended it an honour large enough
For the most valiant liuing; but to dare
Oppose me single, though he lost the day,
VVhat should afflict you, you are free as I,
To be my prisoner, is to be more free,
Then you were formerlie; and neuer thinke
The man I held worthy to combat me,
Shall be vs'd seruilly: Thy ransome is
To take my onely sister to thy wife;
A heauy one Tigranes: for shee is
A Ladie that the neighbour Princes send
Blanks to fetch home: I haue beene too vnkind
To her Tigranes, shee but nine yeere old,
I left her, and nere saw her since: your warres
Haue held m long, and taught me, though a youth,
The way to victorie: shee was a pretty childe
Then, I was little better; but now fame
Cries loudly on her, and my Messengers
Make me beleeue shee is a miracle;
Sheele make you shrinke as I did, with a stroke
But of her eye Tigranes.
Is it the course of
Iberia, to vse their prisoners thus?
Had Fortune throwne my name aboue Arbaces,
I should not thus haue talkt: for in Armenia
vve hold it base; you should haue kept your temper,
Till you saw home agen; where tis the fashion
Perhaps to brag.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Bee you my witnesse Earth:
Neede I to brag, doth not this captiue Prince
Speake me sufficiently, and all the Acts
That I haue wrought vpon his suffering Land?
Should I then boast? Where lies that foot of ground
Within his whole Realme, that I haue not past
Fighting, and Conquering? Farre then from mee
Be oftentation: I could tell the World
How I haue laid his Kingdome desolate
With this sole arme, propt by Diuinity,
Stript him out of his glories, and haue sent
The pride of all his youth to people graues,
And made his Virgins languish for their loues;
If I would brag, Should I that haue the power
To teach the Neighbour world humility,
Mix with vaine glory.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: In deede this is none?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Tigranes, no; did I but take delight
To stretch my deedes as others doe on words,
I could amaze my hearers▪

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: So you doe:

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: But he shall wrong his, and my modesty
That thinkes me apt to boast: After an Act
Fit for a God to doe vpon his foe,
A little glory in a Souldiers mouth,
Is well becomming, bee it farre from vaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Its pitty that valour should be thus drunke.

SP.SPEAKER: Arba.
SP.L: I offer you my Sister, and you answere,
I doe insult: A Lady that no suit
Nor treasure, nor thy Crowne could purchase thee,
But that thou faughst with mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Tigr.
SP.L: Though this bee worse
Then that you spoke before, it strikes not mee
But that you thinke to ouer-grace mee with
The marriage of your Sister, troubles mee,
I would giue worlds for ransomes were they mine,
Rather then haue her.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: See if I insult
That am the Conqueror, and for a ransome
Offer rich treasure to the conquered,
Which he refuses, and I beae his scorne.
It cannot be selfe flattery to say,
The daughters of your Country set by her
Would see their shame; runne home, and blush to death
At their owne foulenesse, yet shee is not faire,
Nor beautifull, those words expresse her not,
They say her lookes are something excellent,
That wants a name yet: were shee odious
Her birth deferues the Empire of the world.
Sister to such a Brother, that hath tane
Victorie prisoner, and throughout the Earth
Carries her bound; and should hee let her loose,
Shee durst not leaue him. Nature did her wrong
To print continuall conquest on her cheekes,
And make no man worthy for her to take,
But mee that am too neare her; and as strangely
Shee did for mee: But you will thinke I brag.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.L: I doe Ile be sworne. Thy Valour and thy passions seuerd, would haue made two excellent fellowes in their kindes: I know not whether I should be sorry thou art so va∣liant, or so passionate▪ would one of vm were away.

SP.SPEAKER: Tigr.
SP.L: Doe I refuse her that I doubt her worth▪
Were shee as vertuous as shee would be thought,
So perfect, that no owne of her owne sex
Would finde a want, had shee so tempting faire,
That shee could wish it off her damning soules,
I would pay any Ransome, twentytimes,
Rather then meet her married in my bed:
Perhaps I haue a Loue, where I haue fixt
Mine eies, not to bee moou'd, and shee on mee▪
I am not fickle:

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Is that all the cause?
Thinke you, you can so knit your selfe in loue
To any other, that her searching sight
Cannot dissolue it? So before you tride
You th ught your selfe a match for mee in fight:
Trust mee Tigranes shee can doe as much
In peace, as I in Warre; sheele conquer too
You shall see, if you haue the power to stand
The force of her swift lookes, if you dislike,
Ile send you home with loue, & name your ransome
some other way: but if shee bee your choise
Shee frees you: to Ileria you must.

SP.SPEAKER: Tigr.
SP.L: Sir, I haue learnt a Prisoners sufferance,
And will obey, but giue mee leaue to talke
In priuate with some friends before I goe.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Some two await him forth, and see him safe,
But let him freely send for whom he please,
And none dare to disturbe his conference:
I will not haue him know what bondage is Exe.
Till he be freefrom mee. This Prince Mardonius
Is full of vvisdome, Valour, all the graces
Man can receiue.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: And yet you Conquered him?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: And yet I conquered him, & could haue don
Hadst thou ioynd with him, thogh thy name in Armes
Bee great; Must all men that are vertuous
Thinke suddenly to match themselves with mee:
I conquered him, and brauely; did I not?

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: And please your Maiesty I was afraid at first.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: When wert thou other?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Of what?

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: That you would not haue spide your best aduantages, for your Maiesty in my opinion lay too high me thinkes, vn∣der fauour, you should haue laine thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Like a Taylor at a vvake.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: And then, ift please your Maiesty to remember, at one time, by my Troth, I wisht my selfe with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: By my Troth thou wouldst haue sunke vm both out oth lifts.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: vvhat to doe?

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: To put your Maiesty in mind of an occasion; you lay thus, and Tigranes falsified a blow at your leg, which you by doing thus auoided; but if you had whipt vp your leg thus, and reacht him on th'eare, you had made the bloud runne abouts head.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: vvhat contry-fence-schoole didst thou learn that at?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Puft, did I not take him nobly?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: VVhy you did, and you haue talkt enough on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Talke enough,
vvhile you confine my words, by Heauen and Earth,
I weremuch better bee a King of Beasts
Then such a people: If I had not patience
Aboue a god, I should be cald a Tyrant
Throughout the VVorld. They will offend to death
Each minute: Let me heare thee speake againe
Andthou art earth againe: vvhy this is like
Tigranes speech▪ that needs would say, I brag'd.
Bessus hee said I brag'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: Ha ha ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: VVhy dost thou laugh?
By all the world I me growne ridiculous
To my owne subiects: Tye me to a chaire
And iest at mee, but I shall make a start
And punish some, that other will take heede
How they are haughty; who will answere mee?
He said I boasted, speak Mardonius,
Did I? He will not answer: O my Temper!
I giue you thankes aboue, that taught my heart
Patience, I can indure his silence; what will none
Vouchsafe to giue mee audience, am I growne
To such a poore respect or doe you meane
To breake my wind, speake, speak soone one of you▪
Or else by Heauen,

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Gent.
SP.P: So please your,

SP.SPEAKER: Arb
SP.L: Monstrous,
I cannot bee heard out, they cut me off
As if I were too sawcy; I will liue
In vvoods, and talke to Trees they will allow mee
To end what I begin. The meanest Subiect
Can finde a freedome to dis harge his soule,
And not I, now it is a time to speake,
I harken.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Gent.
SP.P: May it please,

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: I meane not you,
Did not I stop you once? but I am growne
To balke, but I desire, let another speake.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Gent.
SP.P: I hope your Maiesty,

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Thou drawest thy words
That I must waite an hower, where other men
Can heare in instants; throw your words away
Quicke, and to purpose, I haue told you this.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: An't please your Maiesty:

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Wilt thou deuoure me? this is such a rudenes
As yet you neuer shewed mee, and I want
Power to command mee, else Mardonius
Would speake at my request; were you my King,
I would haue answered at your word Mardonius,
I pray you speake, and true y, did I boast?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Truth will offend you.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: You take all great care what will offend me,
When you dare to vttter such things as these.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.L: You told Tigranes, you had won his Land
With that sole arme propt by Diuinity:
Was not that bragging, and a wrong to vs
That daily venturoe liues?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: O that thy name
Were great as mine, would I had paid my wealth,
It were as great, that I might combate the;
I would through all the Regions habitable
Search thee, and hauing found thee, with my Sword
Driue thee about the vvorld, till I had met
Some place that yet mans curiosity
Hath mist of; there, there would I strike thee dead:
Forgotten of Manind, such Funerall Rites
As Beasts would giue thee thou shouldst haue

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.L: The King
Rage▪ extremely, shall wee flinke away;
Heele strike vs:

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Gent.
SP.P: Content.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: There I would make you know t'was this sole arme,
I grant you were my Instruments, and did
As I commanded you, but t'was this Arme
Mou'd you like wheeles, it mou'd you as it pleas'd:
vvhither slip you now? what are you too good
To waite on mee? I had neede haue temper
That rule such people; I haue nothing left
At my owne choise, I would I might be priuate:
Meane men enioy themselues, but tis our curse,
To haue a tumult that out of their loues
vvill waite on vs whether we will or no;
vvill you be gone? why heere they stand like death,
My word mooues nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Gent.
SP.P: Must we goe?

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: I know not.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb
SP.L: I pray you leaue me Sirs, I'me proud of this,
That they will be intreated from my sight:
vvhy now they leaue mee all: Mardonius,

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: vvill you leaue me quite alone? me thinks
Ciuility should teach you more then this,
If I were but your friend: stay heere, and waite.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Sir, shall I speake?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: vvhy you would now thinke much
To bee denie, but I can scarce intreat
vvhat I would haue: doe, speake.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: But will you heare mee out?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: vvith me you article to talke thus: well
I will heare you out.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Sir, that I haue euer loued you, my sword hath spo∣ken for me, that I doe, if it bee doubted, I dare call an oath a∣great one to my witnesse: and were you not my King, from amongst men, I should haue chose you out to loue aboue the rest:nor can this challenge thanks: for my own sake I should haue doted, because I would haue lou'd the most deseruing man, for so you are.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Alas Mardonius, rise, you shall not kneele;
vve all are Souldiers, and all venter liues:
And where there is no difference in mens worths,
Titles are iests: who can out vallew thee?
Mardonius thou hast lou'd me, and hast wrong,
Thy loue is not rewarded, but beleeue
It shall be better, more then friend in armes,
My Father, and my Tutor, good Mardonius.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar▪
SP.P: Sir, you did promise you would heare me out.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: And so I will, speake freely, for from thee
Nothing can come but worthy things and true.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Though you haue al this worth, you hold som qualities that doe eclipse your vertues.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Eclipse my vertue?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Yes your passions, which are so manifold, that they appeare euen in this: when I commend you, you hug mee for that truth: when I speak of your faults, you make a start, and flie the hearing: but,

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: vvhen you commend me? O that I should liue
To neede such commandations: If my deedes
Blew not my praise themselues aboue the earth,
I were most wretched: spare your idle praise:
If thou didst meane to flatter, and should'st vtter
vvords in my praise, that thou thoughtst impudence,
My deedes should make vm modest: when you praise,
I hug you; 'tis so false, that wert thou worthy
Thou should'st receiue a death, a glorious death
From me: but thou shalt vnderstand thy lies,
For shouldst thou praise mee into Heauen, and there
Leaue me inthron'd, I would despise thee though
As much as now, which is as much as dust,
Because I see thy enuy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: How euer you will vse me after, yet for your owne promise sake heare me the rest.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: I will, and after call vnto the windes,
For they shall lend as large an eare as I
To what you vtter: speake.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: vvould you but leaue these hasty tempers, which I doe not say take from you all your worth, but darken vm, then you would shine indeede.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Well.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Yet I would haue you keepe some passions, least men should take you for a god, your vertues are such.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Why now you flatter.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I neuer vnderstood the word, were you no King, & free from these wilde moodes, should I chuse a companion for wit and pleasure, it should bee you, or for honest▪ to en∣terchange my bosme with, it would be you; or wisdome to to giue me counsel, I would pick out you: or vallor to defend my reputation, still I would find out you, for you are fit to fight for all the vvorld, if it could come in question: Now I haue spoke, consider to your selfe, finde out a vse? if so, then what shall fall to mee is not materiall.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Is not materiall: more then ten such liues
As mine Mardonius: it was Nobly said,
Thou hast spoake truth, and boldly, such a truth
As might offend another. I haue bin
Too passionate, and idle, thou shalt see
A swift amendment: But I want those parts
You praise me for: I fight for all the vvorld:
Giue thee a Sword, and thou wilt goe as farre
Beyond mee, as thou art beyond in yeares,
I know thou dar'st, and wilt; It troubles mee
That I should vse so rough a phrase to thee,
Impute it to my folly, what thou wilt,
So thou wilt pardon mee; that thou and I
Should differ thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: vvhy 'tis no matter Sir:

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Faith but tis, but thou dost euer take
All things I doe thus patiently, for which
I neuer can requite thee but with loue,
And that thou shalt bee sure of. hou and I
Haue not bin merry lately: pray thee tell mee
vvhere hadst thou that same iewell in thine care?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: vvhy at the taking of a Towne.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: A vvench vpon my life, a wench Mardonius
Gaue thee that Iewel.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: vvench, they resect not mee, Ime old and rough, and euery limbe about mee, but that which should growes stiffer: lth those businesses I may sweare I am tuely honest: for I pay iustly for what I take, and would bee glad to be at a certainty.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: vvhy doe the wenches incroch vpon thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I by this light doe they.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Didst thou sit at an old rent with vm?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Ye faith.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: And doe they imrooue themselues?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I, ten shillings to mee, euery new yong fellow they come aequainted with.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: How canst liue on't?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Why I thinke I must petition to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Thou shalt take vm vp at my price.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Your price?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: I at the Kings price.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: That may be more then I am worth.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Gent
SP.P: Is he not merry now?

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Gent.
SP.P: I thinke not.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: He is, he is, weele shew our selues.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Bessus I thought you had beene in Iberia by this, bad you hate▪ Gobrias will want entertainment for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: An't please your Maieste I haue a sute.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Ist not lowsie Bessus, what it?

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: I am to carrie a Lady with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Then thou hast two sutes.

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.P: And if I can preferre her to the Ladie Panthan your Maiesties sister, to learne fashions as her friends terme it, it will be worth something to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: So many nights lodgings as tis thither, will not?

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: I know not that, but gold I shall be sure of.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Why thou shalt bid her entertaine her from mee, so thou wilt resolue me one thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.P: Jf I can.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Faith tis a very disputable question, yet I thinke thou canst decide it▪

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.P: Your Maiestie has a good opinion of my vnderstan∣ding.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: I haue so good an opinion of it: 'tis whether thou be valiant.

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.P: Some bodie has tradust me to you: doe you see this sword Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb▪
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: If I doe not make my back-biters eate it to a knife within this weeke, say I am not valiant.

SP.SPEAKER: Mess.
SP.P: Health to your Maiestie.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: From Gobrias?

SP.SPEAKER: Mess.
SP.P: Yes Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: How does he, is he well?

SP.SPEAKER: Mess.
SP.P: In perfect health.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Thanke thee for thy good newes,
A trustier seruant to his Prince there liues not
Then is good Gobrias.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Gent.
SP.P: The King starts backe.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: His blood goes backe as fast:

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Gent.
SP.P: And now it comes againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: He alters strangely.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: The hand of Heauen is on me, be it farre
From me to struggle; if my secret sinnes
Haue pul'd this curse vpon me, lend me teares.
Enough to wash me white, that I may feele
A childlike innocence within my brest;
Which once perform'd, O giue me leaue to stand
As fixt as constancie her selfe, my eyes
Set here vnmou'd, regardlesse of the World,
Though thousand miseries incompasse me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: This is strange, Sir, how doe you?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Mardonius my mother:

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Is shee dead?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Alas, shees not so happie; thou dost know
How shee hath labour'd since my Father died
To take by treason hence this loathed life,
That would but be to serue her, I haue pardon'd
And pardon'd, and by that haue made her fit
To practise new sinnes, not repent the olde;
Shee now has hir'd a slaue to come from thence
And strike me here, whom Gobrias sifting ̇out,
Tooke, and condemn'd, and executed there
The carefulst seruant: Heauen let me but liue
To pay that man; Nature is poore to me,
That will not let me haue as many deathes
As are the times that he hath sau'd my life,
That I might die vm ouer all for him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.L: Sir let her beare her sins on her owne head,
Vex not your selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: VVhat will the world
Conceiue of me? with what vnnaturall sinnes
VVill they suppose me laden, when my life
Is sought by her that gaue it to the world?
But yet he writes me comfort here, my sister
He sayes is growne in beautie, and in grace,
In all the innocent vertues that become
A tender spotlesse maide: shee staines her cheekes
VVith mourning teares to purge her Mothers ill,
And mongst her sacred dew shee mingles prayers,
Her pure oblations for my safe returne:
If I haue lost the dutie of a sonne,
If any pompe or vanitie of state
Made me forget my naturall offices;
Nay farther, if I haue not euerie night
Expostulated with my wandring thoughts,
If ought vnto my Parent they haue err'd,
And cald vm backe: doe you direct her arme
Vnto this foule dissembling heart of mine:
But if I haue beene iust to her, send out
Your power to compasse me, and hold me safe
From searching treason; I will vse no meanes
But prayers: for rather suffer me to see
From mine own veines issue a deadly floud,
Then wash my dangers off with Mothers bloud:

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I nere saw such sudden extremities.

SP.SPEAKER: Tigr.
SP.L: Why, wilt thou haue me die Spaconia,
What should I doe?

SP.SPEAKER: Spa.
SP.L: Nay, let me stay alone,
And when you see Armenia againe,
You shall behold a Toombe more worth then I,
Some friend that either loues me, or my cause,
VVill build me something to distinguish me
From other women: Many a weeping verse
He will lay on, and much lament those maides
That place their loues vnfortunately hight,
As I haue done, where they can neuer reach:
But why should you goe to Iberia?

SP.SPEAKER: Tigr.
SP.L: Alas, that thou wilt aske me; Aske the man
That rages in a feauer, why hee lies
Distemper'd there, when all the other youths
Are coursing ore the Meadowes with their loues?
Can I resist it? am I not a slaue
To him that conquer'd me?

SP.SPEAKER: Spa.
SP.L: That conquer'd thee, Tigranes he has won but halfe of
Thy bodie; but thy minde may be as free
As his, his will did neuer combate thine,
And take it prisoner:

SP.SPEAKER: Tigr.
SP.L: But if hee by force
Conuey my bodie hence, what helpes it me
Or thee to be vnwilling?

SP.SPEAKER: Spa.
SP.L: O Tigranes,
I know you are to see a Ladie there,
To see, and like I feare: perhaps the hope
Of her makes you forget me ere we part,
Be happier then you know to wish: farewell.

SP.SPEAKER: Tigr.
SP.L: Spaconia stay, and heare me what I say:
In short destruction meete me, that I may
See it, and not auoid it when I leaue
To be thy faithfull Louer: part with me
Thou shalt not, there are none that know our loue;
And I haue giuen gold to a Captaine
That goes vnto Iberia from the King,
That he would place a Ladie of our Land
With the Kings sister that is offer'd me;
Thither shall you, and being once got in,
Perswade her by what subtile meanes you can
To be as backward in her loue as I.

SP.SPEAKER: Spa.
SP.L: Can you imagine that a longing maide
VVhen shee beholds you, can be puld away
VVith words from louing you?

SP.SPEAKER: Tigr.
SP.L: Dispraise my health,
My honestie, and tell her I am iealous:

SP.SPEAKER: Spa.
SP.L: VVhy, I had rather loose you: Can my heart
Consent to let my tongue throw out such words,
And I that euer yet spoke what I thought,
Shall find it such a thing at first to lie:

SP.SPEAKER: Tigr.
SP.P: Yet doe thy best.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: VVhat is your Maiestie readie?

SP.SPEAKER: Tigr.
SP.P: There is the Ladie Captaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: Sweet Ladie by your leaue, I could wish my selfe more full of Courtship for your faire sake.

SP.SPEAKER: Spa.
SP.P: Sir I shall find no want of that.

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.P:
Lady, you must haste, I haue receiued new letters from the King, that requires more speed then I expected he
will follow me suddenly himselfe, and beginnes to call for your Maiestie alreadie.

SP.SPEAKER: Tigr.
SP.P: He shall not doe so long.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: Sweet Ladie shall I call you my charge hereafter?

SP.SPEAKER: Spa.
SP.P: I will not take vpon me to gouerne your tongue Sir, you shall call me what you please:

DIV2.HEAD: Actus Secundus Scena Prima.
DIV2.STAGE: Enter Gobrias, Bacurius, Arane, Panthaea, and Mandane, waiting women, with attendance.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.L: MY Lord Bacurius, you must haue regard
Vnto the Queene, shee is your prisoner,
Tis at your perill if shee make escape.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.L: My Lord I know't, shee is my prisoner
From you committed; yet shee is a woman,
And so I keepe her safe: you will not vrge me
To keepe her close, I shall not shame to say
I sorrow for her.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.L: So doe I my Lord.
I sorrow for her that so little grace
Doth gouerne her, that shee should stretch her arme
Against her King, so little womanhood
And naturall goodnesse, as to thinke the death
Of her owne Sonne.

SP.SPEAKER: Ara.
SP.L: Thou know'st the reason why,
Dissembling as thou art, and wilt not speake.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.L: There is a Ladie takes not after you,
Her Father is within her, that good man
Whose teares paid downe his sinnes, marke how shee weeps,
How well it does become her; and if you
Can find no disposition in your selfe
To sorrow, yet by gracefulnesse in her
Find out the way, and by your reason weepe:
All this shee does for you, and more shee needes,
When for your selfe you will not lose a teare,
Thinke how this want of griefe discredits you,
And you will weepe, because you cannot weepe:

SP.SPEAKER: Ara.
SP.L: You talke to me as hauing got a time
Fit for your purpose; but you know I know
You speake not what you thinke.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: I would my heart
Were stone, before my softnesse should be vrg'd
Against my Mother, a more troubled thought
No Virgin beares about her; should I excuse
My Mothers fault, I should let light a life,
In loosing which, a brother and a King
Were taken from me; If I seeke to saue
That life so lou'd, I loose another life
That gaue me being, I shall loose a Mother,
A word of such a sound in a childes eare,
That it strikes reuerence through it: May the will
Of Heauen be done, and if one needes must fall,
Take a poore Virgins life to answere all.

SP.SPEAKER: Ara.
SP.L: But Gobrias let vs talke; you know this fault
Is not in me as in another woman▪

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.P: I know it is not:

SP.SPEAKER: Ara.
SP.P: Yet you make it so.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.P: Why, is not all that's past beyond your helpe?

SP.SPEAKER: Ara.
SP.P: I know it is.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.L: Nay, should you publish it
Before the world, thinke you twill be belieu'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Ara.
SP.P: I know it would not.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.L: Nay, should I ioine with you,
Should we not both be torne? and yet both die
Vncredited?

SP.SPEAKER: Ara.
SP.P: I thinke we should.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.L: Why then
Take you such violent courses? as for me,
I doe but right in sauing of the King
From all your plots.

SP.SPEAKER: Ara.
SP.P: The King?

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.L: I bad you rest with patience, and a time
VVould come for me
To reconcile all to your owne content:
But by this way you take away my power,
And what was done vnknowne, was not by me,
But you, your vrging, being done,
I must preserue mine owne; but time may bring
All this to light, and happily for all.

SP.SPEAKER: Ara.
SP.L: Accursed be this ouercurious braine,
That gaue that plot a birth; accurst this wombe,
That after did conceiue to my disgrace.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: My Lo d Protector, they say there are diuers Letters come from Armenia that Bessus has done good seruice, and brought againe a day by his particular valour: receiu'd you any to that effect?

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.P: Yes, tis most certaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: Ime sorrie fort, not that the day was wonne, but that twas wonne by him; wee held him here a coward, hee did me wrong once, at which I laught, and so did all the world: for, nor I, nor any other held time worth my Sword.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: Health to my Lord Protector, from the King these Letters, and to your grace Madam these:

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.P: How does his Maiestie?

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: As well as conquest by his owne meanes, and his va∣liant commanders can make him▪ your letters will tel you all.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: I will not open mine til doe know
My brothers health; good Captaine is he well?

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: As the rest of vs that fought are:

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: But howes that, is he hurt?

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: Hees a strange Souldier that gets not a knock,

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: I doe not aske how strange that Souldier is That gets no hurt; but whether he haue one?

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: He had diuers.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: And is he well againe?

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: VVell againe, ant please your grace; why I was run twice through the bodie, and shot ith head with a crosse ar∣row, and yet am well againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: I doe not care how thou dost, is he well?

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P:
Not care how I doe, let a man out of the mightinesse
of his spirit fructifie forraigne Countries with his bloud for the good of his owne, and thus he shall be answered: why, I may liue to relieue with speare and shield such a Ladie di∣stressed.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: Why, I will care, I am glad that thou art well; I prethee is he so?

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.P: The King is well, and will be here to morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: My prayers are heard; now I will open mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.L: Bacurius, I must ease you of your charge:
Madam, the wonted mercie of the King
That ouertakes your faults, has met with this,
And strucke it out; he has forgiuen you freelie,
Your owne will is your Law, be where you please▪

SP.SPEAKER: Ara.
SP.P: I thanke him

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.L: You will be readie
To waite vpon his Maiestie to morrow?

SP.SPEAKER: Ara.
SP.P: I will.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.L: Madam, be wise hereafter:
I am glad I haue lost this Office.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.L: Good Captaine Bessus, tell vs the discourse
Betweene Tigranes and our King, and how
We got the victorie.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: I prethee doe,
And if my brother were in any danger,
Let not thy tale make him abide there long,
Before thou bring him off; for all that while
My heart will beate.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: Madam, let what will beate, I must tell truth, and thus it was: They fought single in lists but one to one, as for my own part I was dangerouslie hurt but three dayes before, else perhaps wee had beene two to two; I cannot tell, some thought wee had; and the occasion of my hurt was this, the enemie had made trenches.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.P: Captaine, without the manner of your hurt be much materiall to this businesse, weele heare it some other time.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: I, I prethee leaue it, and goe on with my brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: I will, but 'twould be worth your hearing: To the lists they came, and single sword and gauntlet was their fight.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: Alas.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: Without the lists there stood some dozen Captaines of either side mingled, all which were sworne, and one of those was I: and twas my chance to stand neee a Captaine of the Enemies side, called Tiribasus; valiant they said he was: whilst these two Kings were stretching themselues, this Tiri∣basus cast something a scornefull looke on mee, and askt mee whom I thought would ouercome: I smilde, and told him, if hee would fight with me, he should perceiue by the euent of that whose King would winne; something hee answered, and a scuffle was like to grow, when one Zipetus offerd to helpe him: I—

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: All this is of thy selfe, I prethee Bessus
Tell something of my brother, did he nothing?

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: Why yes, Ile tell your Grace; they were not to fight till the word giuen, which for my owne part by my troth I was not to giue.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: See, for his owne part.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: I feare yet this fellowe's abusd with a good report.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: I, but I:

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: Still of himselfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: Cride, giue the word, when as some of them saide Ti∣granes was stooping, but the word was not giuen then: when one Cosros of the enemis part held vp his finger to me, which is as much with vs Marshallists, as I will fight with you: I said not a word, nor made signe during the combate; but that once done.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: He slips ore all the fight.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: I cald him to me, Cosros said I:

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: I will heare no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: No, no, Ilie.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: I dare be sworne thou dost.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: Captaine said I, twas so.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: I tell thee, I will heare no further.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: No, your Grace will wish you had.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: I will not wish it: what is this the Ladie
My Brother writes to me to take?

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P:
An't please your Grace this is shee: Charge will
you come neerer the Princes?

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: Y'are welcome from your Countrey, and this Land
Shall shew vnto you all the kindnesses
That I can make it; what's your name?

SP.SPEAKER: Spa.
SP.P: Thalestris.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: Y are verie welcome, you haue got a letter
To put you to me, that has power enough
To place mine Enemy here; then much more you,
That are so farre from being so to me,
That you nere saw me.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes
SP.P: Madam, I dare passe my word for her truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Spa.
SP.P: My truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan
SP.P: Why Captaine, doe you thinke I am afraid sheele steale?

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: I cannot tell, seruants are slipperie; but I dare giue my word for her, and for her honestie: shee came along with me, and many fauours shee did me by the way; but by this light none but what shee might doe with modestie, to a man of my ranke.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan
SP.P: Why Captaine, heres no body thinkes otherwise.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: Nay, if you should, your Grace may thinke your plea∣sure; but I am sure I brought her from Armenia, and in all that way if euer I toucht any bare on her aboue her knee, I pray God I may sinke where I stand.

SP.SPEAKER: Spa.
SP.P: Aboue my knee?

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: No▪ you know I did not, and if any man will say I did, this Sword shall answere: Nay, Ile defend the reputation of my charge whilst I liue; your Grace shall vnderstand I am se∣cret in these businesses, and know how to defend a Ladies honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Spa.
SP.L: I hope your Grace knowes him so well already,
I shall not neede to tell you hee's vaine and foolish:

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: I, you may call mee what you please, but Ile defend your good name against the World; and so I take my leaue of your Grace, and of you my Lord Protector, I am likewise glad to see your Lordship well.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: O Captaine Bessus, I thanke you, I would speake with you anon.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: When you please, I will attend your Lordship:

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: Madam, Ile take my leaue too:

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: Good Bacurius:

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.P: Madam, what writes his Maiesty to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: O my Lord,
The kindest words, Ile keepe vm whilst I liue
Here in my bosome; theres no art in vm,
They lie disordred in this paper, Iust
As hearty Nature speakes vm.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.L: And to mee
He writes, what teares of ioy he shed to heare
How you were growne in euery vertuous way,
And yeilds all thankes to me, for that deare care
Which I was bound to haue in training you:
There is no Princes liuing that enioyes
A Brother of that worth.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: My Lord, no Maide longs more for any thing, or feeles more heate and cold within her brest, then I doe now, In hope to see him.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.P: Yet I wonder much at this, hee writes he brings a∣long with him a husband for you, that same Captiue Prince;
SP.L: And if he loue you as he makes a shew,
He will allow you freedome in your choise.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: And so he will my Lord, I warrant you
He will but offer, and giue me the power
To take▪ or leaue.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.L: Trust me, were I a Ladie I could not like
That man were bargain'd with before I chuse him.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan
SP.L: But I am not built on such wild humors,
If I find time worthy, he is not lesse,
Because hee▪s offerd.

SP.SPEAKER: Spa.
SP.P: Tis true, he is not, would he would seem lesse:

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.L: I thinke there is no Ladie can affect
Another Prince, your Brother standing by;
He does eclipse mens vertues so with this.

SP.SPEAKER: Spa.
SP.L: I know a Lady may, and more I feare
Another Lady will.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: Would I might see him:

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.L: Why so you shall: my businesses are great,
I will attend you when it is his pleasure
To see you Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: I thanke you good my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.P: You will be ready Madam:

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Spa.
SP.L: I doe beseech you Madam send away
Your other women, and receiue from me
A few sad words, which set against your ioyes,
May make vm shine the more.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: Sirs leaue me all.

SP.SPEAKER: Spa.
SP.L: I kneele a stranger here to beg a thing
Vnfit for me to aske, and you to grant,
Tis such another strange ill laid request,
As if a beggar should intreat a King
To leaue his Scepter and his Throne to him,
And take his rags to wander ore the World
Hungry and cold.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: That were a strange request.

SP.SPEAKER: Spa.
SP.P: As ill is mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: Then doe not vtter it.

SP.SPEAKER: Spa.
SP.L: Alas, tis of that nature, that it must
Be vtterd, I, and granted, or I die:
I am asham'd to speake it; but where life
Lies at the stake, I cannot thinke her woman,
That will not take something vnreasonably
To hazard sauing of it: I shall seeme
A strange petitioner, that wish all ill
To them I beg of, ere they giue mee ought,
Yet so I must: I would you were not faire,
Nor wise, for in your ill consists my good:
If you were foolish, you would heare my prayer;
If foule, you had not power to hinder me:
He would not loue you.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: VVhats the meaning of it?

SP.SPEAKER: Spa.
SP.L: Nay, my request is more without the bounds
Of reason yet; for tis not in the power
Of you to doe what I would haue you grant.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: VVhy then tis idle, prethee speake it out.

SP.SPEAKER: Spa.
SP.L: Your brother brings a Prince into this Land
Of such a noble shape, so sweete a grace,
So full of worth withall, that euery maide
That lookes vpon him, giues away her selfe
To him for euer; and for you to haue
He brings him: and so mad is my demand,
That I desire you not to haue this man,
This excellent man, for whom you needs must die,
If you should misse him. I doe now expect
You should laugh at me.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: Trust me, I could weepe
Rather, for I haue found in all thy words
A strange disiointed sorrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Spa.
SP.L: Tis by me,
His owne desire too, that you would not loue him.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: His owne desire, why credit me Thalestris
I am no common wooer: If he shall wooe me,
His worth may be such, that I dare not sweare
I will not loue him; but if he will stay
To haue me wooe him, I will promise thee
He may keepe all his graces to himselfe,
And feare no rauishing from me.

SP.SPEAKER: Spa.
SP.L: Tis yet
His owne desire, but when he sees your face,
I feare it will not be; therefore I charge you
As you haue pitty, stop those tender eares
From his inchanting voice, close vp those eyes,
That you may neither catch a dart from him,
Nor he from you: I charge you as you hope
To liue in quiet, for when I am dead
For certaine I shall walke to visit him,
If he breake promise with me: for as fast
As oathes without a formall ceremony
Can make me, I am to him:

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: Then be fearelesse,
For if he were a thing twixt God and man,
I could gaze on him; (if I knew it sinne,
To loue him) without passion: Dry your eyes,
I sweare you shall enioy him still for me,
I will not hinder you; but I perceiue
You are not what you seeme: Rise, rise, Thalestris.
If your right name be so.

SP.SPEAKER: Spa.
SP.L: Indeed it is not
Spaconia is name; but I desire
Not to be knowne to others:

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: Why, by me
You shall not, I will neuer doe you wrong,
What good I can, I will; thinke not my birth,
Or education such, that I should iniure
A stranger Virgin: you are welcome hither.
In company you wish to be commanded,
But when we are alone, I shall be ready
To be your seruant.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter three men, and a woman.

SP.P: Come, come, run, run, runne:
We shall out-goe her.
One were better be hang'd, then carry women out fid∣ling to these shewes.

SP.SPEAKER: Weo.
SP.P: Is the King hard by?
You heard hee with the bottles say, hee thought wee should come too late, what abundance of people here is.

SP.SPEAKER: Weo.
SP.P: But what had he in those bottles?
I know not.
Why, Inke good man foole:
Inke, what to doe?
Why, the King looke you, will many times call for those bottles, and breake his minde to his friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Weo.
SP.P: Lets take our places quickly, we shall haue no roome else.
The man told vs hee would walke a foote through the people.
I marry did he.
Our shops are well looke to now:
S'life yonders my Master I thinke.
No, tis not he.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter two Citizens wiues, and Philip.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Cit.
SP.P: Lord, how fine the fields be, what sweete liuing tis in the Countrey.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Cit.
SP.P: I, poore soules, God helpe vm; they liue as conten∣tedly as one of vs.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Cit.
SP.P: My Husbands cousen would haue had me gone in∣to the Countrey last yeere, wert thou euer there?

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Cit.
SP.P: I, poore soules, I was amongst vm once.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Cit.
SP.P: And what kinde of creatures are they for loue of God?

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Cit.
SP.P: Very good people, God helpe vm:

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Cit.
SP.P: Wilt thou goe with me downe this summer, when I am brought abed?

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Cit.
SP.P: Alas, tis no place for vs.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Cit.
SP.P: VVhy prethee?

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Cit.
SP.P: VVhy, you can haue nothing there; theres no body cries broomes.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Cit.
SP.P: No?

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Cit.
SP.P: No truly, nor milke.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Cit.
SP.P: Nor milke, how doe they?

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Cit.
SP.P: They are faine to milke themselues ith Countrey.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Cit.
SP.P: Good Lord: but the people there I thinke will bee very dutifull to one of vs?

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Cit.
SP.P: I, God knowes will they, and yet they doe not great∣ly care for our Husbands.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Cit.
SP.P: Doe they not, alas? In good faith I cannot blame them: for we doe not greatly care for them our selues. Philip I pray choose vs a place.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: Theres the best forsooth.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Cit.
SP.P: By your leaue good people a little:
VVhats the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: I pray my friend doe not thrust my Mistris so, shees with childe.
Let her looke to her selfe then, has shee not had thrusting enough yet; if shee stay shouldring here, shee may hap to goe home with a Cake in her bellie.
How now goodman squitterbreech, why doe you leane so on me?

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: Because I will.
VVill you sir sawce-box?

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Cit.
SP.P: Looke if one haue not strucke Philip, come hither Philip, why did he strike thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: For leaning on him.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Cit.
SP.P: VVhy didst thou leane on him?

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: I did not thinke he would haue strucke me.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Cit.
SP.P: As God saue me law, thou art as wilde as a Bucke, there is no quarrell, but thou art at one end or other of it.
Its at the first end then; for he will neuer stay the last.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Cit.
SP.P: VVell stripling, I shall meete with you.
vvhen you will.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Cit.
SP.P: Ile giue a crowne to meete with you▪
At a bawdy house.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Cit.
SP.P: I, you are full of your rogery; but if I doe meete you it shall cost me a fall.

SP.L: The King, the King, the King, the King:
Now, now, now, now.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Arbaces, Tigranes, Mardonius, and others.

SP.SPEAKER: All
SP.P: God preserue your Maiestie.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: I thanke you all: Now are my ioyes at full,
vvhen I behold you safe my louing Subiects;
By you I grow, tis your vnited loue
That lifts me to this height:
All the account that I can render you
For all the loue you haue bestowed on me,
All your expences to maintaine my warre,
Is but a little word: you will imagine
Tis slender payment; yet tis such a word
As is not to be bought without our blouds;
Tis peace.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: God preserue your Maiestie.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Now you may liue securely in your Townes,
Your Children round about you; you may sit
Vnder your vines, and make the miseries
Of other Kingdomes a discourse for you,
And lend them sorrowes: For your selues you may
Safely forget there are such things as teares;
And may you all whose good thoughts I haue gain'd,
Hold me vnworthy, when I thinke my life
A sacrifice too great to keepe you thus
In such a calme estate:

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: God blesse your Maiestie.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: See all good people, I haue brought the man,
Whose very name you fear'd, a captiue home:
Behold him, tis Tigranes; in your hearts
Sing songs of gladnesse, and deliuerance.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Cit.
SP.P: Out vpon him.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Cit.
SP.P: How he looks.

SP.SPEAKER: 3 Weo.
SP.P: Hang him, hang him, hang him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar
SP.P: These are sweete people.

SP.SPEAKER: Tigr.
SP.L: Sir, you doe me wrong,
To render me a scorned spectacle
To common people.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: It was farre from me
To meane it so: if I haue ought deseru'd,
My louing Subiects let me beg of you
Not to reuile this Prince, in whom their dwels
All worth of which the nature of a man
Is capable; valour beyond compare,
The terror of his name has stretcht it selfe
Where euer there is sunne: and yet for you,
I fought with him single, and won him too;
I made his valour stoope, and made that name
Soar'd to so vnbelieu'd a height, to fall
Beneath mine: This inspir'd with all your loues,
I did performe, and will for your content
Be euer ready for a greater worke.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: The Lord blesse your Maiestie.

SP.SPEAKER: Tigr.
SP.P: So, hee has made me amends now, with a speech in commendations of himselfe: I would not be so vaine-glo∣rious.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: If there be any thing in which I may
Doe good to any creature, here speake out;
For I must leaue you: and it troubles me,
Thus my occasions for the good of you,
Are suchas ca lles me from you; else my ioy
Would be to spend my dayes amongst you all.
You shew your loues in these large multitudes
That come to meete me: I will pray for you,
Heauen prosper you, that you may know old yeeres,
And liue to see your Childrens Children
Fate at your boards with plenty: when there is
A want of any thing, let it be knowne
To me, and I will be a Father to you:
God keepe you all.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: God blesse your Maiestie.
Come, shall we goe, all's done.

SP.SPEAKER: Weo.
SP.P: I for Gods sake, I haue not made a fire yet:
Away, away, all's done.
Content: Farewell Philip.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Cit.
SP.P: Away, you haltersack you:
Philip will not fight hee's afraid on's face.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.P: I marry am I afraid of my face.
Thou wouldst be Philip, if thou saw'st it in a glasse; it lookes like a visor.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Cit.
SP.P: Youle be hang'd sirra: Come Philip, walke afore vs homeward; did not his Maiestie say, he had brought vs home Peaes for our money?

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Cit.
SP.P: Yes marry did he.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Cit.
SP.P: They are the first I heard on this yeere by my troth, I long'd for some of vm; did he not say we should haue some?

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Cit.
SP.P: Yes, and so we shall anon I warrant you, haue euery one a pecke brought home to our houses.

DIV2.HEAD: Actus Tertij Scaena Prima.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: MY Sister take it ill?

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.L: Not very ill,
Something vnkindly shee doth take it Sir,
To haue her Husband chosen to her hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: VVhy Gobrius te her; I must haue her know
My will, and not her owne must gouerne her:
VVhat, will shee marrie with some slaue at home?

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.L: O shee is farre from any stubbornnesse,
You much mistake her, and no doubt will like
VVhere you wil haue her; but when you behold her,
You will be loath to part with such a Iewell.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: To part with her, why Gobrius art thou mad? shee is my sister▪

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.L: Sir, I know shee is:
But it were pitty to make poore our Land
With such a beauty, to inrich another.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Pish, will shee haue him?

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.P: I thinke shee will Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: VVere shee my Father, and my Mother too;
And all the names for which we think folkes friends,
Shee should be forcst to haue him, when I know
Tis fit: I will not heare her say shee's loth.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.L: Heauen bring my purpose luckily to passe,
You know tis iust: Sir, sheele not neede constraint,
Shee loues you so.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: How does shee loue me, speake?

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.L: Shee loues you more then people loue their health
That liue by labour; more then I could loue
A man that died for me, if he could liue againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Shee is not like her Mother then?

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.L: O no, when you were in Armenia,
I durst not let her know when you were hurt:
For at the first on euery little scratch,
Shee kept her chamber, wept, and would not eate,
Till you were well; and many times the newes
vvas so long comming, that before we heard,
Shee was as neare her death, as you your health.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb▪
SP.L: Alas poore soule, but yet shee must be rul'd;
J know not how I shall requite her well,
I long to see her; haue you sent for her,
To tell her I am ready?

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.P: Sir, I haue.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.P: Sir, here's the Armenian King.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Hees welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.P: And the Queene Mother, and the Princes waite with∣out:

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Good Gobrius bring them in,
Tigranes you will thinke you are arriu'd
In a strange Land, where Mothers cast to poyson
Their onely sonnes; thinke you you shall be safe?

SP.SPEAKER: Tigr.
SP.P: Too safe I am ▪

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Gobrius, Aran, Pantha, Spaconia, Bacurius, Mardonius, and Bessus.

SP.SPEAKER: Ara.
SP.L: As low as this I bow to you, and would
As low as to my graue, to shew a mind
Thankefull for all your mercies.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: O stand vp,
And let me kneele, the light will be asham'd
To see obseruance done to me by you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ara.
SP.P: You are my King.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: You are my Mother rise;
As farre be all your faults from your owne soule,
As from my memory; then you shall be
As white as innocence her selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Ara.
SP.L: I came
Onely to sew my dutie, and acknowledge
My sorrow for my sinnes; longer to stay
Wee but to draw eyes more attentiuely
vpon my shame: That power that kept you safe
From me preserue you still.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Your owne desires shall be your guard.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan
SP.L: Now let me die,
Since I haue seene my Lord the King returne
In safety, I haue seene all good that life▪
Can shew me; I haue nere another wish▪
For Heauen to grant, nor were it fit I should:
For I am bound to spend my age to come
In giuig than kes that this was granted me.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.P: vvhy does not your Maiestie speake?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: To whom?

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.P: To the Princesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: Alas Sir, I am fearefull, you doe looke
On me, as if I were some loathed thing
That you were finding out a way to shunne.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.P: Sir, you should speake to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Ha?

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: I know I am vnworthy, yet not ill,
Arm'd▪ with which innocence here I will kneele,
Till I am one with earth: but I will gaine
Some words, and kindnesse from you.

SP.SPEAKER: Tigr.
SP.P: vvill you, speake Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Speake, am I what I was?
vvhat art thou that dost creepe into my breast,
And darst not see my face shew forth thy selfe▪
I feele a paire of fierie wings displaide
Hither, from thence; you shall not tarrie there,
vp, and be gone, if thou beest loue, be gone,
Or I will teare thee from my wounded flesh,
Pull thy lou'd downe away, and with a quill
By this right arme drawne from thy wanton wing,
vvrite to thy laughing Mother in thy bloud,
That you are Powers belied, and all your darts
Are to be blowne away by men resolu'd
Like dust; I know thou fear'st my words, away.

SP.SPEAKER: Tigr.
SP.L: O miserie, why should he be so slow▪
There can no falshood come of louing her,
Though I haue giuen my faith; shee is a thing
Both to be lou'd and seru'd beyond my faith:
I would he would present me to her quicklie.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: vvill you not speake at all, are you so farre
From kind words? yet to saue my modesty
That must talke till you answer: doe not stand
As you were dumbe, say something, though it be
Poyson'd with anger that may strike me dead:

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.L: Haue you no life at all? for manhood sake
Let her not kneele, and talke neglected thus;
A tree would find a tongue to answer her,
Did shee but giue it such a lou'd respect.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: You meane this Lady, lift her from the earth;
Why doe you let her kneele so long? alas,
Madam your beauty vses to command,
And not to beg; what is your sute to me?
It shall be granted, yet the time is short,
And my affaires are great: but wheres my sister?
I bad shee should be brought.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: What is he mad?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Gobrius, where is shee?

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.P: Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Where is shee man?

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.P: Who Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Who, hast thou forgot? my Sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.P: Your Sister Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Your Sister Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.P: Some one that has a wit, answere; where is shee?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Doe you not see her there?

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.P: Where?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: There.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.P: There, where?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: S'light there, are you blind?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Which doe you meane, that little one?

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.P: No Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: No Sir, why doe you mocke me? I can see.
No other here, but that petitioning Ladie:

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.P: Thats shee.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Away.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.P: Sir it is shee:

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Tis false.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.P: Is it?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: As hell, by Heauen as false as hell,
My sister: Is shee dead? if it be so,
Speake boldly to me: for I am a man,
And dare not quarrell with diuinity;
But doe not thinke to cosen me with this:
I see you all are mute, and stand amas'd,
Fearefull to answere me; it is too true
A decreed instant cuts off euery life,
For which to mourne, is to repine; shee died
A Virgin though, more innocent then sleeps,
As cleere as her owne eyes, and blessednesse
Eternall waites vpon her where shee is:
I know shee could not make a wish to change
Her state for new, and you shall see me beare
My crosses like a man; we all must die,
And shee hath taught vs how.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.L: Doe not mistake,
And vex your selfe for nothing; for her death
Is a long life of I hope: Tis shee,
And if my speech deserue not faith, lay death
Vpon me, and my latest words shall force
A credit from you.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Which good Gobrius,
That Ladie dost thou meane?

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.P: That Lady Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: It cannot be.

SP.SPEAKER: Tigr.
SP.L: Pish, this is tedious,
I cannot hold, I must present my selfe;
And yet the sight of my Spaconia,
Touches me, as a sudden thunderclap
Does one that is about to sinne.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Away,
No more of this; here I pronounce him Traytor,
The direct plotter of my death that names,
Or thinkes her for my Sister: Tis a lie,
The most malicious of the World, inuented
To mad your King; he that will say so next,
Let him draw out his Sword, and sheath it here,
It is a sinne fully as pardonable:
Shee is no kinne to me, nor shall shee be;
If shee were any, I create her none,
And which of you can question this, my power
Is like the Sea, that is to be obey'd,
And not disputed with: I haue decreed her
As farre from hauing part of bloud with me,
As the nak'd Indians: Come, and answer me,
He that is boldest now; Is that my Sister?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: O this is fine.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.L: No marry is shee not an't please your Maiestie:
I neuer thought shee was, shees nothing like you.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: No, tis true, shee is not:

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Thou shouldst be hang'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: Sir, I will speake but once: By the same power
You make my bloud a stranger vnto yours;
You may command me dead, and so much loue
A stranger may importune, pray you doe;
If this request appeare too much to grant,
Adopt me of some other Family
By your vnquestion'd word; else I shall liue
Like sinfull issues that are left in streetes
By their regardlesse Mothers, and no name
Will be found for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: I will heare no more;
Why should there be such musicke in a voice,
And sinne for me to heare it: All the world
May take delight in this, and tis damnation
For me to doe so; you are faire, and wise,
And vertuous I thinke, and he is blest
That is so neere you as your brother is:
But you are naught to me but a disease,
Continuall torment without hope of ease;
Such an vngodly sicknesse I haue got,
That he that vndertakes my cure, must first
Orethrow Diuinity, all morall Lawes,
And leaue mankinde as vnconfinde as beasts,
Allowing them to doe all actions
As freely as they drinke, when they desire.
Let me not heare you speake againe; yet so
I shall but languish for the want of that,
The hauing which would kill me: No man here
Offer to speake for her; for I consider
As much as you can say: I will not toyle
My body, and my mind too, rest thou there,
Heres one within will labour for you both.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: I would I were past speaking.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.L: Feare not Madam,
The King will alter, tis some sudden change,
And you shall see it end some other way.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: Pray God it doe.

SP.SPEAKER: Tigr.
SP.L: Though shee to whom I swore be here, I cannot
Stifle my passion longer: If my Father
Should rise againe disquieted with this,
And charge me to forbeare, yet it would out:
Madam, a stranger, and a prisoner begs
To be bid welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: You are welcome Sir
I thinke, but if you be not, tis past me
To make you so: for I am here a stranger,
Greater then you: we know from whence you come,
But I appeare a lost thing, and by whom
Is yet vncertaine; found here in the Court,
And onely sufferd to walke vp and downe,
As one not worth the owning.

SP.SPEAKER: Spa.
SP.L: O, I feare
Tigranes will be caught, he lookes me thinkes
As he would change his eyes with her; some helpe
There is aboue for me I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Tigr.
SP.L: VVhy doe you turne away, and weepe so fast,
And vtter things that misbecome your lookes,
Can you want owning?

SP.SPEAKER: Spa
SP.P: O, tis certaine so.

SP.SPEAKER: Tigr.
SP.P: Acknowledge your selfe mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: How now?

SP.SPEAKER: Tigr.
SP.P: And then see if you want an owner,

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: They are talking.

SP.SPEAKER: Tigr.
SP.P: Nations shall owne you for their Queene.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Tigranes, art not thou my prisoner?

SP.SPEAKER: Tigr.
SP.P: I am.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: And who is this?

SP.SPEAKER: Tigr.
SP.P: Shee is your Sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Shee is so.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Is shee so againe, thats well:

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: And how dare you then offer to change words with her?

SP.SPEAKER: Tigr.
SP.L: Dare doe it, why you brought me hither Sir
To that intent.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Perhaps I told you so,
If I had sworne it, had you so much follie
To credit it: The least word that shee speakes
Is worth a life: rule your disorderd tongue,
Or I will temper it.

SP.SPEAKER: Spa.
SP.P: Blest be that breath.

SP.SPEAKER: Tigr.
SP.L: Temper my tongue; such inciuilities
As these, no barbarous people euer knew:
You breake the law of Nature, and of Nations;
You talke to me, as if I were a prisoner
For theft: my tongue be temperd? I must speake
If thunder checke me▪ and I will.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: You will.

SP.SPEAKER: Spa.
SP.P: Alas my Fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Tigr.
SP.P: Doe not feare his frowne, deare Madam heare me.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Feare not my frowne: but that 'twere base in me
To fight with one I know I can orecome,
Againe thou shouldst be conquerd by me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: He has one ransome with him already, me thinkes twere good to fight double, or quit.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Away with him to prison; Now Sir see
If my frowne be regardlesse: why delay you?
Seize him Bacurius, you shall know my word
Sweepes like a wind, and all it grapples with▪
Are as the chaffe before it.

SP.SPEAKER: Tigr.
SP.P: Touch me not.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Helpe there.

SP.SPEAKER: Tigr.
SP.P: Away.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Gent.
SP.P: It is in vaine to struggle.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Gent.
SP.P: You must be forc't.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: Sir, you must pardon vs, we must obey.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Why doe you dally there? Drag him away
By any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: Come Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Tigr.
SP.L: Iustice, thou oughtst to giue me strength enough
To shake all these off: This is tyranie
Arbaces, subtiller then the burning Buls,
Or that fam'd Tyrants bed. Thou mightst as well
Search in the depth of winter through the Snow
For halfe staru'd people, to bring home with thee
To shew vm fire, and send vm backe againe,
As vse me thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Let him be close Bacurius.

SP.SPEAKER: Spa.
SP.L: I nere reioyc'd at any ill to him,
But this imprisonment: what shall become
Of me forsaken?

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.L: You will not let your sister
Depart thus discontented from you Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: By no meanes Gobrius, I haue done her wrong,
And made my selfe beleeue much of my selfe,
That is not in me: you did kneele to me,
Whilst I stood stubborne and regardlesse by;
And like a god incensed, gaue no eare
To all your prayers: behold, I kneele to you,
Shew a contempt as large as was my owne,
And I will suffer it; yet at the last forgiue me.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: O you wrong me more in this,
Then in your rage you did: you mocke me now.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Neuer forgiue me then, which is the worst
Can happen to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: If you be in earnest,
Stand vp, and giue me but a gentle looke,
And two kind words, and I shall be in Heauen.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Rise you then to; here I acknowledge thee
My hope, the onely Iewell of my life,
The best of sisters, dearer then my breath,
A happinesse as high as I could thinke;
And when my actions call thee otherwise,
Perdition light vpon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: This is better
Then if you had not frown'd, it comes to me
Like mercy at the blocke; and when I leaue
To serue you with my life, your curse be with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Then thus I doe salute thee, and againe
To make this knot the stronger; Paradice
Is there: It may be you are still in doubt,
This, this third kisse▪ blots it out. I wade in sinne,
And foolishly intice my selfe along:
Take her away, see her a prisoner
In her owne chamber▪ closely Gobrius.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: Alas Sir, why?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: I must not stay the answere, doe it.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: Good Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: No more, doe it I say.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: This is better and better.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: Yet heare me speake.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: I will not heare you speake;
Away with her, let no man thinke to speake
For such a creature: for shee is a witch,
A poysoner, and a raytor.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: Madam, this Office grieues me.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.P: Nay, tis well the King is pleas'd with it.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Bessus, goe you along too with her; I will proue
All this that I haue said, if I may liue
So long: but I am desperately sicke,
For shee has giuen me poyson in a kisse;
Shee had it twixt her lips, and with her eyes
Shee witches people: go without a word. Exeunt omnes, pr.
Why should you that haue made me stand in war Ar. Mar.
Like fate it selfe, cutting what threds I pleas'd,
Decree such an vnworthy end of me,
And all my glories? what am I alas,
That you oppose me? If my secret thoughts
Haue euer harbour'd swellings against you,
They could not hurt you, and it is in you
To giue me sorrow, that will render me
Apt to reeiue your mercy; rather so,
Let it be rather so, then punish me
VVith such vnmanly sinnes: Incest is in me
Dwelling alreadie, and it must be holie
That pulles it thence; where art Mardonius?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Here Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: I prethee beare me, if thou canst;
Am I not growne a strange weight?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: As you were.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: No heauier?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar
SP.P: No Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: VVhy, my legs
Refuse to beare mybodie; O Mardonius,
Thou hast in field beheld me, when thou know'st
I could haue gone, though I could neuer runne.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: And so I shall againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb
SP.P: O no, tis past.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Pray ye goe, rest your selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: VVilt thou hereafter when they talke of me,
As thou shalt heare nothing but infamie;
Remember some of those things.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Yes, I will.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: I prethee doe: for thou shalt neuer see me so again.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I warrant ye.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P:
They talke of fame, I haue gotten it in the warres, and will affoord any man a reasonable penny-worth: some will say they could be content to haue it, but that it is to be atchieued with danger; but my opinion is otherwise: for if I might stand still in Canon proofe, and haue fame fall vpon me, I would refuse it: My reputation came principally by thinking to runne away, which no bodie knowes but Mar∣donius▪ and I think he conceales it to anger me. Before I went to the warres, I came to the Towne a young fellow without meanes, or parts, to deseue friends; and my emptie guts per∣swaded me to lie, and abuse people for my meate, which I did, and they beate me: then would I fast two dayes, till my hunger cride out on me, raile still; then me thought I had a monstrous stomacke to abuse them againe, and did it. In this state I continued till they hung me vp by th'heeles and beate me with hasle sticks, as if they would haue baked mee, and haue cosen'd some bodie with mee for Venison: After this I rail'd, and ate quietlie: for the whole Kingdome tooke notice of me for a baffel'd whipt fellow, and what I said, was remembred in mirth, but neuer in anger; of which I was glad,
I would it were at that passe againe: After this, God cald an Ant of mine, that left two hundred pounds in a Cosens hand for me, who taking me to be a gallant young spirit, rais'd a company for mee with the money, and sent me into Armenia with vm: Away I would haue runne from them, but that I could get no company, and alone I durst not run. I was neuer at battle but once, and there I was running, but Mardonius cudgel'd me; yet I got loose at last, but was so afraid, that I saw no more then my shoulders doe, but fled with my whole company amongst my enemies, and ouerthrew vm: Now the report of my valor is come ouer before mee, and they say I was a raw young fellow, but now I am improu'd. A plague of their eloquence, twill cost me many a beating: And Mar∣donius might helpe this to if he would; for now they thinke to get honour of me, and all the men I haue abus'd, call me freshly to account, worthily as they call it, by the way of challenge.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.P: Good morrow Captaine Bessus.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: Good morrow Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.P: I come to speake with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: You are very welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.P: From one that holds himselfe wronged by you some three yeers since: your worth he sayes is fam'd, & he nothing doubts but you will doe him right, as beseemes a Souldier.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: A pox on vm, so they crie all.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.P: And a slight note I haue about me for you, for the deliuerie of which, you must excuse me; it is an office that friendship calles vpon mee to doe, and no way offensiue to you, since I desire but right on both sides.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: Tis a challenge Sir, is it not?

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.P: Tis an inuiting to the field.

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.P: An inuiting? O crie you mercie, what a complement he deliuers it with? he might as agreeablie to my nature pre∣sent mee poyson with such a speech: vm reputation, vm call you to an account, vm forst to this, vm with my sword, vm like a gentleman, vm deare to me, vm satisfaction: Tis verie well Sir, I doe accept it, but he must awaite an answere this thirteene weekes.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.P: Why Sir, he would be glad to wipe off his staine as soone as hee can, Sir vpon my credit I am already ingag'd to two hundred and twelue, all which must haue their staines wipt off, if that be the word before him.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.P: Sir, if you be truly ingaged but to one, he shall stay a competent time.

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.P: Vpon my faith Sir to two hundred and twelue, and I haue a spent bodie too much bruis'd in battle, so that I can∣not fight, I must be plaine with you, aboue three combates a day: All the kindnesse I can doe him, is to set him resolutely in my rowle the two hundred and thirteenth man, which is something: for I tell you, I thinke there will be more after him, then before him, I so pray ye commend me to him, and tell him this.

SP.SPEAKER: Gent.
SP.P: I will Sir, good morow to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.P: Good morow good Sir. Certenly my safest way were to print my selfe a coward, with a discouerie how I came by my credit, and clap it vpon euery post: I haue recei∣ued aboue thirty challenges within this two houres, marry all but the first put off with ingagement, and by good for∣tune the first is no madder of fighting then I, so that that's re∣feru'd. The place where it must be ended, is foure dayes iour∣ney of, and our arbytrators are there: He has chosen a gen∣tleman in trauell, and I haue a speciall friend, with a quar∣terne ague likely to hold him this time here, for mine; and when his man comes home, wee are to expect my friends health: If they would send me challenges thus thicke, as long as I liu'd I would haue no other liuing; I can make seauen shillings a day o th paper to the Grocers: yet I learne nothing by all these but a little skill in comparing of stiles. I doe find euidently that there is some one Scriuener in this Towne, that has a great hand in writing of challenges, for they are all of a cut, and six of vm in a hand; and they all end, my reputation is deare to me, and I must require satisfaction: whose there? more paper I hope; no, tis my Lord Bacurius, I feare all is not well betwixt vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: Now Captaine Bessus, I come about a friuilous mat∣ter, caus'd by as idle a report: you know you were a coward.

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.P: Very right.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: And wrong'd me.

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.P: True my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: But now people will call you valiant, desertlesly I thinke yet for their satisfaction, I wil haue you fight with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.P: O my good Lord, my deepe ingagements.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: Tell not me of your ingagements, Captaine Bessus; it is not to be put off with an excuse: for my owne part, I am none of the multitude that beleeue your conuersion from coward.

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.P: My Lord, I seeke not quarrels, and this belongs not to me, I am not to maintaine it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: Who then pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.P: Bessus the coward wrong'd you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: Right.

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.P: And shall Bessus the valiant, maintaine what Bessus the coward did?

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: I prethee leaue these cheating trickes, I sweare thou shalt fight with mee, or thou shalt be beate extreamely, and kickt.

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.P: Since you prouoke me thus farre my Lord, I will fight with you; and by my Sword it shall cost me twenty pounds, but I will haue my legge a weeke sooner purposely.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: Your legge, why what ailes your legge? Ile doe a cure on you, stand vp.

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.P: My Lord, this is not noble in you:

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.L: What dost thou with such a phrase in thy mouth?
I will kicke thee out of all good words before I leaue thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.L: My Lord, I take this as a punishment for the offence
I did when I was a coward.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: When thou wert? confesse thy selfe a coward still, or by this light, Ile beate thee into spunge.

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.P: Why I am one:

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: Are you so Sir, and why doe you weare a sword then? Come, vnbuckle, quicke.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: My Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: Vnbuckle I say, and giue it mee, or as I liue, thy head will ake extreamely.

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.P: It is a pretty hilt, and if your Lordship take an affecti∣on to it, with all my heart, I present it to you for a new-yeers gift.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: I thanke you very heartily, sweete Captaine farewell.

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.P: One word more, I beseech your Lordship to render me my knife againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: Marry by all meanes Captaine, cherish your selfe with it, and eate hard good Captaine; we cannot tell whe∣ther we shall haue any more such: A due deare Captaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.P: I will make better vse of this, then of my sword: A base spirit has this vantage of a braue one; it keepes alwayes at a stay, nothing brings it downe, not beating. I remember I promist the King in a great audience, that I would make my back-byters eate my sword to a knife, how to get another sword I know not, nor know any meanes left for me to main∣taine my credit but impudence: Therefore will I outsweare him and all his followers, that this is all is left vneaten of my sword.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
