SP.P: Ile mone the King, hee is most strangely alter'd; I guesse the cause I feare too right, Heauen has some secret end in't, and tis a securge no question iustly laid vpon him: Hee has followed mee through twenty roomes, and euer when I stay to await his command, he blushes like a girle, and lookes vpon me, as if modestie kept in his businesse: so turnes away from me, but if I goe on, hee followes me againe. See, here he is, I doe not vse this, yet I know not how, I cannot chuse but weepe to see him: his very enemies I thinke, whose wounds haue bred his fame, if they should see him now, would find teares in their eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: I cannot vtter it, why should I keepe
A breast to harbour thoughts? I dare not speake:
Darkenesse is in my bosome, and there lies
A thousand thoughts that cannot brooke the light;
How wilt thou vex me when this deede is done
Conscience? that art afraid to let me name it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: How doe you Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Why very well Mardonius; how dost thou?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Better then you I feare.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: I hope thou art; for to be plain with thee,
Thou art in hell else: secret scorching flams
That farre transcend earthly materiall fiers,
Art crept into me, and there is no cure;
Is not that strange Mardonius, theres no cure?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.L: Sir, either I mistake, or there is something hid
That you would vtter to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: So there is, but yet I cannot doe it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Out with it Sir, i it be dangerous I shall not shrinke to doe you seruice, I shal no este my life a waightier mat∣ter then indeed it is, I nw tis subict to more chances then it hath houes, and I were better loose it in my King cause, then with an gue. or fall, or sleepin to a thie; as all these are roable enog: let me ut know ha I shal do foryou.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: It will not out: were you with Gobrius,
And bad him giue my sister all content
The place affoords, and giue her leaue to send
And speake to whom shee please?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Yes Sir▪ I was.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb
SP.L: And did you to Bacurius say as much
About Tigranes?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Thats all my businesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar
SP.L: O say not so,
You had an answere of all this before,
Besides, I th ne this businesse might be vtterd
More careleslie.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Come, thou shalt haue it out; I doe beseech thee
By all the loue thou hast profest to me,
To see my Sister from me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: VVell, and what?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Thats all.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar
SP.P: That's strange, shall I say nothing to her?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb
SP.L: Not a word;
But if thou louest me, find some subtill way
To make her vnsterstand by signes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: But what▪ what s old I make her vnderstand?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: O Mardonius, for that I must be pardon'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: You may, but I can onelie see her then.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Tis true;
Beare her this ring then, and on more aduice
Thou shalt speake to her: Tell her I doe loue
My kindred all; wilt thou?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar▪
SP.P: Is there no more?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: O yes, and her the best;
Better then any brother loues his sister: That's all.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.L: Me thinkes this
Neede not haue beene deliuered with such caution;
Ile doe it.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb:
SP.L: There is more yet,
VVilt thou be faithfull to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.L: Sir▪ if I take vpon me to deliuer it,
After I heare it, He passe through fire to doe it▪

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: I loue her better then a brother ought;
Dost thou conceue me?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I hope I doe not Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: No, thou art dull, kneele downe before her▪
And nere rise againe, till shee will loue me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: VVhy, I thinke shee does.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: But better then shee does, another way;
As wiues loue Husbands.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.L: Why, I thinke there are few wiues that loue their
Husbands better then shee does you.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Thou wilt not vnderstand me: is it fit
This should bee vtterd plainle; take it then
Naked as it is: I would desire her loue
Lasciuiouslie, leudlie, incestuouslie,
To doe a sinne that needs must damne vs both;
And thee to▪ Dost thou vnderstand me now?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.L: Yes, there's your Ring againe; what haue I done
Dishonestlie in my whole life, name it▪
That you should put so base a businesse to me?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb
SP.P: Didst thou not tell mee thou wouldst doe it?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.L: Yes▪ if I vndertooke it; but if all
My heires were liues, I would not be ingag'd
In such a cause o saue my last life.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: O guilt, how poore, and weake a thing art thou?
This man that is my seruant, whom my breath
Might blow about the world, might beate me here
Hauing his cause, whilst I prest downe with sinne
Could not resist him, deare Mardonius
It was a motion misbeseeming man.
And I am sorrie for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Pray God you may be so: you must vnderstand, no∣thing that you can vtter, can remooue my loue and seruice from my Prince. But otherwise, I thinke I shall not loue you more. For you are sinnefull, and if you doe this crime, you ought to haue no lawes. For after this it will bee great iniu∣stice in you to punish any offendor for any crime: For my selfe I find my heart too bigge, I feele I haue not patience to looke on whilst you runne these forbidden courses: Meanes I haue none but your Fauour, and I am ather glad, that I shall loose vm both together▪ then keepe vm with such con∣ditions, I shall find a dwelling amongst some people, where though our garments perhaps be courser, we shall be richer arre within, and harbor no such vices in vm. God preserue you, and mend you.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Mardonius, stay Mardonius, For though
My presnt state require nothing but knaus
To be about me, such as are prepar'd
For euery wicked act▪ yet who does know
But that my loathed Fate may turne about,
And I haue vse of honest men againe:
I hope I may, I prethy leaue me not.

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.P: Where is the King?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: There.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: An't please your Maiestie, ther's the knife.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: What knife:

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: The Sword is eaten.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.L: Away you Foole▪ the King is serious,
And cannot now admit your vanities.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: Vanities, I am no honest man if my enemies haue not brought it to this, what, doe you thinke I lie?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: No, no, tis well Bessus, tis very well,

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.L: I am glad ont'.
If your enemies brought it to that, your enemies are cutlers,
Come, leaue the King.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb
SP.L: No, let him stay Mardonius, let him stay,
I haue occasions with him very weightie,
And I can spare you now.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Why I can spare you now.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: Mardonius giue way to the state affayres

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Indeed you are fitter for his present purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Bessus I should imploy thee; wilt thou do't

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: Doe for you, by this ayre I will doe any thing with∣out exception, be it a good, bad, or indifferent thing▪

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Do not sweare.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.L: By this light but I will,
Any thing whatsoeuer.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: But I shall name a thing
Thy conscience will not suffer thee to doe.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes▪
SP.P: I would faine heare that thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Why I would haue thee get my Sister for me:
Thou vnderstands me in a wicked manner.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.L: O you would haue about with her?
Ile do't, Ile do't Ifaith.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Wilt thou, dost make no more ant?

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: More, no, why is there any thing else, if there be tell me, it shall be done.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Hast thou no greater sence of such a sinne?
Thou art too wicked for my company
Though I haue hell within me, and mayst yet
Corrupt me further: pray thee answere me
How doe I shew to thee after this motion?

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: VVhy your Maiestie lookes as well in my opinion as euer you did since you were borne:

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: But thou appearest to me after thy grant
The vgliest, loathed, detestable thing
That I haue euer met with. Thou hast eyes
Like flames of Sulphur, which me thinkes doe dart
Infection on me, and thou hast a mouth
Enough to take me in, where there doe stand
Fower rowes of Iron teeth.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P:
I feele no such thing, but tis no matter how I looke, Jle doe your businesse as well as they that looke better, and
when this is dispatcht, if you haue a minde to your Mother tell me, and you shall see Ile set it hard:

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: My Mother, Heauen forgiue me to heare this,
I am inspir'd with horror: I hate thee
Worse then my sinne, which if I could come by,
Should suffer death eternall, nere to rise
In any breast againe. Know I will die
Languishing mad, as I resolue I shall,
Ere I will deale by such an Instrument:
Thou art too sinfull to imploy in this;
Out of the world, away.

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.P: What doe you meane Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Hung round with curses, take thy fearefull flight in∣to the desarts, where mongst all the monsters,
If thou findst one fo beastly as thy selfe,
Thou shalt be held as innocent.

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.P: Good Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: If there were no such Instruments as thou,
We Kings could neuer act such wicked deeds:
Seeke out a man that mockes Diuinitie,
That breakes each precept both of Gods and Mans,
And Natures too, and does it without lust;
Merely because it is a law, and good,
And liue with him: for him thou canst not spoile.
Away I say; I will not doe this sinne.
Ile presse it here till it doe breake my breast;
It heaues to get out: but thou art a sinne
And spight of torture, I wil keep thee in.

DIV2.HEAD: Actus Quarti Scaena Prima.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.P: HAue you written Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: Yes, good Gobrias.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.L: And with a kindnesse, and suh winning words
As may prouoke him at one instant fee e
His double fault, your wrong, and his owne rashnesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: I haue sent words enough, if words may winne him
From his displeasure, and such words I hope
As shall gaine much vpon his goodnesse, Gobrius:
Yet fearing since th'are many, and a womans,
A poore beliefe may follow; I haue wouen
As many truthes within vm to speake for me,
That if he be but gracious, and receiue vm.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.L: Good Ladie, be not fearefull; if he should not
Gie vou your present end in this beleeue it
You sha l feele (if your vertue can induce you
To labour out this temest, which I know
Is but a poore proofe gainst your patience▪)
All those contents your spirit will arriue at
Newer and sweeter to you; your royall brother
(VVhen he shall once collect himselfe, and see
How farre e beene asunder from himselfe,
What a meere stranger to his golden temper)
Mst from those rootes of vertue, (neuer dying
Though somewhat stopt with humour) shoote againe
Into a thousand glories bearing his fa re branches
Hie as our hopes can looke at straight as Iustice,
Loden with ri e contents: he loues you dearely,
I know it, and I hope I neede not further
Winne you to vnderstand it.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: I beleeue it,
Howsoeuer I am sure I loue him dearely,
So dearely, that if any thing I write
For my inlarging, should bege hi anger;
Heauen e a itnesse with mee, and my faith
I had rather liue inomb'd here.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.P: You shall not feele a vorse stroke then your griefe, I am sorr tis so sharpe: I kisse your hand, and this night will deliuer this true storie with this hand to your bro∣ther.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: Peace goe with you,
You are a good man; my paconia
VVhy are you euer sad thus?

SP.SPEAKER: Spa.
SP.L: O deere Ladie.
Many, and strange ones,
I feele my olde fire flame againe, and burne
So strong and violent, that should I see her
Againe, the griefe, and that would kill me .

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.L: Your token I acknowledge, you may passe;
There is the King.

SP.SPEAKER: Spac.
SP.P: I thanke your Lordship for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Tigr.
SP.L: Shee comes, shee comes, shame hide me euer from her; would I were buried, or so farre remou'd
Light might not find me out: I dare not see her.

SP.SPEAKER: Spac.
SP.L: Nay, neuer hide your selfe; for were you hid
vvhere earth hides all her riches, nere her center;
My wrongs without more day would light me to you:
I must speake ere I die; were all your greatnesse
Doubled vpon you, y'are a periur'd man,
And onely mighty in the wickednesse
Of wronging women. Thou art salfe, false Prince,
I liue to see it: poore Spaconia liues
To tell thee thou art false; and then no more:
Shee liues to tell thee thou art more vnconstant
Then all ill women euer were together;
Thy faith as firme as raging ouerflowes,
That no banke can command; and as lasting
As boyes gay bubbles blowne in the aire, and broken:
The wind is fixt to thee, and sooner shall
The beaten Marriner with his shrill whistle,
Calme the loude murmurs of the troubled maine,
And strike it smooth againe; then thy soule fall
To haue peace in loue with any: Thou art all
That all good men must hate, and if thy storie
Shall tell succeeding ages what thou wert,
O let it spare me in it, lest true Louers
In pitty of my wrongs burne thy blacke legend,
And with their curses shake thy sleeping ashes.

SP.SPEAKER: Tigr.
SP.L: Oh, oh:
The destinies I hope haue pointed out
Our ends alike, that thou maist die for loue,
Though not for me: for this assure thy selfe,
The Princesse hates thee deadly, and will sooner
Be wonne to marrie with a Bull, and safer,
Then such a beast as thou art: I haue strucke
I feare too deepe; beshrow me fort: Sir,
This sorrow workes me like a cunning friendship,
Into the same piece with it; hee's asham'd,
Alas▪ I haue beene too rugged: Deare my Lord,
I am sorrie I haue spoken any thing,
Indeed I am, that may adde more restraint
To that too much you haue: Good Sir be pleas'd
To thinke it was a fault of loue, not malice;
And doe as I will doe: forgiue it Prince,
I doe, and can forgiue the greatest sinnes
To me you can repent of; pray belieue▪me.

SP.SPEAKER: Tigr.
SP.L: O my Spaconia! O thou vertuous woman!

SP.SPEAKER: Spa.
SP.L: No more, the King Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Haue you beene carefull of our noble Prisoner
That he want nothing fitting for his greatnesse?

SP.SPEAKER: Bac▪
SP.P: I hope his grace will quit me, for my care Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Tis well, royall Tigranes health.

SP.SPEAKER: Tig.
SP.P: More then the stricktnesse of this place can giue Sir I offer backe againe to great Arbaces.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: VVe thanke you worthy Prince, and pray excuse vs,
We haue not seene you since your being here,
I hope your noble vsage has beene equall
With your owne Person: your imprisonment
If it be any, I dare say is eafie,
And shall not outlast two dayes.

SP.SPEAKER: Tigr.
SP.L: I thanke you:
My vsage here has beene the same it was
Worthy a royall Conquerour. For my restraint
It came vnkindly, because much vnlookt for;
But I must beare it:

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: VVhat Lady is that Bacurius?

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: One of the Princesse women Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: I feard it: why comes shee hether!

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: To speake with the Prince Tigranes.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: From whom Bacurius?

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: From the Princesse Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: I know I had seene her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mardo.
SP.L: His fit beginnes to take him now againe
Tis a strange Feauer, and twill shake vs all
SP.P: Anone I feare; would he were well cur'd of this raging folly: Giue me the warres, where men are mad, and may talke what they list, and held the brauest Fellowes; This pelting prat∣ling peace is good for nothing: drinking's a vertue to it:

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: I see theres truth in no man, nor obedience,
But for his owne ends, why did you let her in?

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.L: It was your owne command to barre none from him,
Beside the Princesse sent her Ring Sir
For my warrant.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: A token to Tigranes, did she not:
Sirra tell truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.L: I doe not vse to lye Sir,
Tis no way I eate or liue by, and I thinke
This is no token Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: This combat has vndone him: If he had beene well beaten, he had beene temperate: I shal neuer see him hansome againe, till he haue a Horse-mans staffe poak't through his shoulders, or an arme broke with a Bullet.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: I am trifled with.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: I know it, as I know thee to be false.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Now the clap comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.L: You neuer knew me so Sir, I dare speake it,
And durst a worse man tell me though my better.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Tis well said by my Soule.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb
SP.P: Sirra you answere as you had no life.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: That I feare Sir to loose nobly.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb
SP.P: I say Sir once againe

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: You may say Sir what you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: would I might doe so.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: I will Sir, and say openly this woman carries letters, by my life I know she carries letters, this woman does it:

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P:
VVould Bessus were here to take her aside and search
her, he would quickly tell you what she carried Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: I haue found it out, this woman carries letters.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar
SP.P: If this hold twill be an ill world for Bauds, Cham∣ber-maids, and post-boyes, I thanke God I haue none but his letters pattents, things of his owne inditing.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb
SP.P: Prince this cunning cannot doe it.

SP.SPEAKER: Tig.
SP.P: VVhat Sir, I reach you not.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: It shall not serue your turne Prince.

SP.SPEAKER: Tig.
SP.P: Serue my turne Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb
SP.P: Sir it shall not serue your turne.

SP.SPEAKER: Tig.
SP.P: Be plainer good Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: This woman shall carry no more letters backe to your loue Panthaea, by heauen she shall not, I sa she shall not.

SP.SPEAKER: Mardo.
SP.P: This would make a Saint sweare like a Souldier, and a Souldier like termogant.

SP.SPEAKER: Tig.
SP.P: This beates me more King then the blowes you gaue me.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Take vm away both, and together let vm be priso∣ners, stricktly and closely kept, or Sirra your life shall answere it; and let no bodie speake with vm hereafter.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: Well I am subiect to you, and must endure these pas∣sions.

SP.SPEAKER: Spa.
SP.P: This is the imprisonment I haue lookt for alwayes, and the deare place I would chuse.
SP.STAGE: Ex. Bacu. with Tig. and Spa.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Sir, haue you done well now?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Dare you reproue it?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: You must be crossing me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.L: I haue no letters Sir to anger you,
But a dry sonnet of my Corporals
To an old Sadlers wife, and that Ile burne Sir:
Tis like to proue a fine age for the Ignorant.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: How darest thou so often forfeit thy life,
Thou knowest tis in my power to take it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Yes, and I know you wonnot, or if you doe, youle misse it quicklie.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Why?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.L: Who shall then tell you of these childish follies
When I am dead? Who shall put to his power
To draw those vertues out of a floud of humours
Where they are drownd, and make vm shine againe?
No cut my head off: doe, kill me:
Then you may talke, and be beleeud, and grow,
And haue your too selfe-glorious temper rot
Into a dead sleepe, and the kingdome with you,
Like forraigne swords be in your throats, and slaughter
Be euery where about you like your flatterers.
Doe, kill me.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Prethee be tamer good Mardonius,
Thou knowst I loue thee, nay I honour thee:
Beleeue it good old Souldier I am all thine:
But I am rackt cleane from my selfe, beare with me,
Woot thou beare with me good Mardonius.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.L: There comes a good man, loue him too, hees tempe∣rate,
You may liue to haue need of such a vertue,
Rage is not still in fashion.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: VVelcome good Gobrius.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.P: My seruice, and this letter to your grace.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: From whom?

SP.SPEAKER: Go.
SP.L: From the rich mine of vertue, and all beautie,
Your mournefull Sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: She is in prison Gobrius, is shee not?

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.L: She is Sir till your pleasure doe enlarge her,
Which on my knees I beg; O tis not fit
That all the sweetnesse of the world in one;
The youth, and vertue, that would haue wilde Tygers
And wilder people, that haue knowne no manners
Should liue thus Cloysterd vp, For your loues sake
(If there be any in that Noble heart)
To her a wretched Ladie, and forlorne,
Or for her loue to you, (which is as much
As Nature, and obedience euer gaue)
Haue pittie on her beauties.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Prethee stand vp, tis true she is too Faire,
And all these commendations but her owne:
VVould thou hadst neuer so commended her,
Or I nere liu'd to haue heard it, Gobrius;
If thou but knew of the wrong her beautie does her,
Thou wouldst in pittie of her be a lyar:
Thy ignorance has drawne me wretched man
VVhether my selfe nor thou canst well tell, O my Fate,
I thinke shee loues me; but I feare another
Is deeper in her heart: how thinkst thou Gobrius?

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.L: I doe beseech your Grace beleeue it not,
For let me perish if it be not false:
Good Sir reade her letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: This loue, or what a diuell is it, I know not, be∣gets more mischiefe then a wake. I had rather be we I beaten staru'd, or lowsie, then liue within the aire ont. He that had seene this braue fellow charge through a groue of pykes but tother day, and looke vpon him now, will nere beleeue his eyes againe; If he continue thus but two daies more, a Taylor may beat him with one hand tyed behind him.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Alas she would be at libertie,
And there be thousand reasons Gobrius
That will denie it:
Which if she knew, she would contentedly
Be where she is and blesse her vertue for it,
And me though she were closer, She would Gobrius,
Good man indeed she would.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.L: Then good Sir for her satisfaction
Send for her, and with reason make her know
VVhy she must liue thus from you.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: I will goe bring her to me.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Bessus, and two Sword-men, and a Boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.L: Y' are verie welcome both, some stooles there boy,
And reach a Table; Gentlemen oth' Sword,
Pray sit without more complement: be gone childe,
I haue beene curious in the searching of you,
Because I vnderstood you wise, and valiant persons.

SP.P: vve vnderstand our selues Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.L: Nay Gentlemen, and my deare friends oth' Sword,
No complement I pray; but to the cause
I hang vpon, which in few, is my honour.
You cannot hang too much Sir for your honour,
But to your cause, be wise, and speake truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.P: My first doubt is my beating by my Prince.

SP.L: Stay there a little Sir, doe you doubt a beating,
Or haue you had a beating by your Prince.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: Gentlemen ath'sword, my Prince has beaten me.
Brother what thinke you of this case
If he haue beaten him, the case is cleare.

SP.L: If he haue beaten him I grant the case;
But how? VVe cannot be too subtill in this businesse
I say, but how?

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: Euen with his royall hand.
Was it a blow of loue or indignation.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.L: T was twentie blowes of indignation gentlemen,
Besides two blowes ath'face.
Those blowes ath'face haue made a new case ont',
The rest were but an honourable rudnesse▪

SP.P: Two blowes oth'face, and giuen by a worse man, I must confesse as we Sword-men say, had turnd the businesse: Marke me brother, by a worse man; but being by his Prince, had they beene ten, and those ten drawne ten teeth, beside the hazard of his nose for euer; all these had beene but fauours: This is my flat opinion, which Ile die in.

The King may doe much Captaine beieeue it, for had hee crackt your skull through like a bottle, or broke a rib or two with crossing of you, yet you had lost no honour: This is strange you may imagin; but this is truth now Captaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.L: I will be glad to imbrace it gentleman;
But how farre may he strike me?
Theres another,
A new cause rising from the time, and distance,
In which I will deliuer my opinion:
SP.P: He may strike, beate, or cause to be beaten; for these are natu∣rall to man: your Prince I say may beate you so farre forth as his dominion reacheth; that's for the distance, the time, ten mile a day▪ I take it.

SP.L: Brother you erre, tis fifteene mile a day,
His stage is ten, his beatings are fifteene.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.L: Tis a the longest, but we subiects must
Be subiect to it: you are wise, and vertuous.
Obedience euer makes that noble vse ont,
To which I dedicate my beaten bodie;
I must trouble you a little further Gentlemen oth' Sword.
No trouble at all to vs Sir, if we may
Profit your vnderstanding; we are bound
By vertue of ou calling, to vtter our opinions
Shortly, and disreetly.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: My sorest businesse is, I haue beene kickt.
How farre Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.P: Not to slatter my selfe in it all ouer, my sword forst, but not lost; for disreetely I renderd it to saue that impu∣tation.
It shewed discretion the best part of valour.

SP.L: Brother, this is a pretty case, pray ponder on't,
Our friend here has beene kickt.

SP.P: He has so brother.

SP.L: Sorely he sayes: Now had he sit downe here
Vpon the meere kicke, it had beene cowardly.

SP.P: I thinke it had beene cowardly indeed.

SP.L: But our friend has rdm'd it, in deliuering
His sword without compulsion; and that man
That tooke it of him, I pronounce a weake one,
And his kicks nullities.
He should haue kickt him after the deliuerie,
Which is the confirmation of a coward.
Brother, I take it you mistake the question:
For say that I were kickt.
I must not say so;
Nor I must not heare it spoke byth' tongue of man
You kickt deare brother; you are merrie.

SP.P: But put the case I were kickt?
Lot them put it that are things wearie of their liues, & know not honour: put case you were kickt?
I doe not say I was kickt.
Nor no silly creature, that weares his head without a case, his soule in a skin-coate: you kickt deare brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Bess▪
SP.L: Nay Gentlemen, let vs doe what we shall doe
Truly and honestly; good Sit toth' question.

SP.P: Why then I say, suppose your boy kickt Captaine?
The boy may be suppos'd, hee's lyable; but kicke my brother?

SP.L: A foolish forward zeale Sir in my friend;
But to the boy, suppose the boy were kickt?

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.P: I doe suppose it.
Has your boy a sword?

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.P: Surely no: I pray suppose a sword too.
I doe suppose it: you grant your boy was kickt then.
By no meanes Captaine, let it be suppos'd still; this word grant, makes not for vs.
I say this must be granted.
This must be granted brother?
I, this must be granted.
Still the must:
I say this must be granted.
Giue me the must againe, agine; brother you palter.
I will not heare you waspe.
Brother, I say you palter, the must three times toge∣ther; I weare as sharpe steele as another man,
SP.L: And my Foxe bites as deepe, must my deare brother:
But to the cause againe:

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.P: Nay, looke you Gentlemen.
In a word I ha done.

SP.L: A tall man, but vntemperate; tis great pittie:
Once more suppose the boy kickt.

SP.P: Forward.
And being throughly kickt, laughes at the kicker▪
So much for vs; proceede.

SP.L: And in this beaten scorne, as I may call it,
Deliuers vp his weapon: where lies the error?

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.L: It lies ith beating Sir,
I found it foure dayes since.
The error, and a sore one, as I take it;
Lies in the thing kicking.

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.P: I vnderstand that well, tis sore indeed Sir.
That is according to the man that did it.
There springs a new branch: whose was the fooe?

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.P: Ah Lords.

SP.L: The cause is mightie, but had it beene two Lords,
And both had kickt you, if you laught, tis cleere.

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.L: I did laugh,
But how will that helpe me Gentlemen?

SP.P: Yes, it shall helpe you, if you laught alowd.

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.P: As lowd as a kickt man could laugh, I laught Sir:

SP.L: My reason now; the valiant man is knowne
By suffering and contemning, you haue
Enough of both, and you are valiant.
If he be sure he has beene kickt enough:
For that braue sufferance you speake of brother,
Consists not in a beating, and away,
But in a cudgeld bodie, from eighteene
To eight and thirtie: in a head rebuk't
With pots of all Size, daggers, stooles, and bedstaues,
This shewes a valiant man.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.L: Then I am valiant, as valiant, as the proudest,
For these are all familiar things to me:
Familiar as my sleepe, or want of money.
All my whole bodi's but one bruize with beating,
I thinke I haue beene cudgeld with all nations,
And almost all Religions.
Imbrace him brother, this man is valiant,
I know it by my selfe hees valiant.
Captaine thou art a valiant Gentleman
To abide vpon't, a very valiant man.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: My equall friends ath'sword, I must request your hands to this.
Tis fit it should be.

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.L: Boy get some wine, and pen and inke within:
Am I cleare Gentlemen?
Sir when the world has taken notice what we haue done,
Make much of your bodie, for Ile pawne my steele,
Men will be coyer of their legs hereafter.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: I must request you goe along, and testifie to the Lord Bacurius, whose foot has strucke me, how you find my cause.

SP.L: We will, and tell that Lord he must be rul'd,
Or there be those abroad will rule his Lordship.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Arbaces at ōne doore, Gob▪ and Panthea at another▪

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.P: Sir her's the Princesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Leaue vs then alone.
For the maine cause of her imprisonment
Must not be heard by any but her selfe:
You are welcome Sister, and I would to God
I could so bid you by another name,
If you aboue loue not such sinnes as these▪
Circle my heart with thoughts as cold as snow
To quench these rising flames that harbour here.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: Sir, does it please you, I should speake.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Please me,
I more then all the art of Musicke can;
Thy speech does please me, for it euer sounds
As thou broughts ioyfull vnexpected newes:
And yet it is not fit thou shouldt be heard,
I prethee thinke so.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: Be it so, I will.
I am the first that euer had a wrong
So farre from being fit to haue redresse,
That twas vnfit to heare it; I will backe
To prison rather, then disquiet you,
And waite till it be fit.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: No, doe not goe,
For I will heare thee with a serious thought:
I haue collected all thats man about me
Together strongly, and I am resolud
To heare the largely, but I doe beseech thee
Doe not come neerer to me, for there is
Something in that that will vndo vs both.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: Alas Sir, am I venom?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Yes to me.
Though of thy selfe I thinke thee to be in
As equall a degree of heate, r cold
As Nature can make, yet as sound men
Conuert the sweetest, and the nourishingst meates
Into diseases, so shall I distemperd,
Doe thee, I prethe draw no eerer to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: Sir this is that I would, I am of late,
Shut from the world, and why it should be thus
Is all I wish to know.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: VVhy credit me
Panthaea, credit me that am thy brother,
Thy louing brother, that there is a cause
Sufficient, vet vnfit for thee to knowe,
That might vndoe thee eurlastingly
Onely to hear, wilt thou b credit this;
By heauen is true, bleeu it if thou cant.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: Children a oos are ee credulous;
And I am both I thike, for I bleue:
If you dissemble be it on your head,
Ile backe vnto myrison▪ yet me thinkes
I might be kept in some place where you are:
For in my selfe finde, I know not what
To call it, but it is a great desire
To see you often.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Fie, you come in a step, what doc you meane
Deare Sister▪ doe not so: Alas Pathaea,
Where I am, would you be, why thats the cause
You are imprisond, that you may not be
VVhere I am.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: Then I must endure it Sir, God keepe you.

SP.SPEAKER: Abr.
SP.L: Nay, you shall heare the cause in short Panthaea;
And when thou hearst it, thou wilt blush for me,
And hang thy head downe like a Violet
Full of the mornings dew: There is a way
To gaine thy freedome, but tis such a one
As puts thee in worse bondage, and I know,
Thou wouldst encounter fire, and make a proofe
Whether the Gods haue care of innocents,
Rather then follow it; know I haue lot
The onely difference betwixt man, and beast,
My reason.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: Heauen forbid.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Nay it is gone,
And I am left as farre without a bound,
As the wild Ocean that obeyes the winds;
Each suddaie passon throwes me as it lifts,
And ouerwhelmes all that oppose my will:
I haue beheld thee with a lustfull eye:
My heart is set on wickednesse, to act
Such sinnes with thee, as I haue beene afraid
To thinke off: If thou dar'st consent to this,
(Which I beseech thee doe not) thou maist gaine
Thy libertie, and yeeld me a content:
If not thy dwelling must be darke, and close
VVhere I may neuer see thee; For God knowes
That layd this punishment vpon my pride,
Thy sight at some time will enforce my madnesse
To make a start eye to thy rauishing:
Now spit vpon me, and call all reproaches
Thou canst deuise together; and at once
Hurle vm against me: for I am a sicknesse
As killing as the plague, ready to seize thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: Farre be it from me to ruile the King:
But it is true, that I should rather chuse
To search out death, that else would search out me,
And in a graue sleepe with my innocence,
Then welcome such a sinne: It is my fate,
To these crosse accidents I was ordaind,
And must haue patience; and but that my eyes
Haue more of woman in vm then my heart,
I would not weepe: peace enter you againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Farewell, and good Panthaea pray for me;
Thy prayers are pure, that I may find a death,
How euer soone before my passions grow,
That they forget, what I desire, is sinne;
For thether they are tending: If that happen,
Then I shall force thee, though thou wert a Virgin
By vow to Heauen, and shall pull a heape
Of strange▪ yet vninuented sinnes vpon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: Sir, I will pray for you▪ yet you shall know
It is a sullen ate that gouernes vs.
For I could wish as heartilie as you
I were no sister to you▪ I should then
Imbrace your lawfull loue sooner then health.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Couldst hou affect me then?

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: So perfectly
That as it is, I nere shall sway my heart
To like another.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Then I curse my birth,
Must this be added to my miseries
That thou art willing too, Is there no steppe
To our full happinese, but these meere sounds
Brother and Sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: There is nothing else
But these alas will seperate vs more
Then twentie worlds betwixt vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: I haue liu'd
To conquer men, and now am ouerthrowne
Onely by words, Brother and Sister: where
Haue those words dwelling? I will find vm out
And vtterly destroy them, but they are
Not to be grasp't▪ let vm be men or beasts,
And I will cut vm from the earth, or townes,
And I will rase vm, and then blow vm vp:
Let vm be Seas, and I will drinke them off,
And yet haue vnquencht fire left in my breast:
Let vm be any thing but meerely voice▪

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: But tis not in the power of any Force
Or pollicie to conquer them.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Panthaea,
VVhat shall wee doe? shall we stand firmely here, and gaze our eyes out?

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: Would I could doe so;
But I shall weepe out mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Accursed man,
Thou boughtst thy reason at too deare a rate;
For thou haft all thy actions bounded in
With curious rules, when cuerie Beast is free:
What is there that acknowledges a kindred
But wretched Man? Who euer saw the Bull
Fearefully leaue the Heifer that he likt,
Because they had one Dam?

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: Sir, I disturbe you,
And my selfe too; twere better I were gone:
I will not be so foolish as I was.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Stay, we will loue iust as becomes our birthes,
No otherwise: Brothers and Sisters may
VValke hand in hand together; so will we
Come neerer: Is there any hurt in this?

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: I hope not.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Faith theres none at all:
And tell me truly now, is there not one
You loue aboue me?

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: No by Heauen.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Yet you sent vnto Tigranes Sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: True, but for another: for the truth—

SP.SPEAKER: Arb
SP.L: No more,
Ile credit thee; I know thou canst not lie,
Thou art all truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: But is there nothing else
That we may doe, but onely walke; me thinkes
Brothers and sisters lawfully may kisse.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: And so they may Panthaea, so will we,
And kisse againe too; we were scrupulous
And foolish, but we will be so no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: If you haue any mercy, let me goe
To prison, to my death, to any thing:
I feele a sinne growing vpon my bloud,
Worse then all these, hotter I feare then yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: That is impossible, what should we doe?

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.P: Flie it for Gods sake.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: So we must, away;
Sin growes vpon vs more by this delay.

DIV2.HEAD: Actus Quinti Scaena Prima.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: SIR, the King has seene your Commission, and eleeus it, and freely by this warrant giues you leaue to visit Prince Tigranes your noble Master.

SP.SPEAKER: Lig.
SP.P: I thanke his Grace, and kisse his hanes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: But is the maine of all your businesse Ended in this?

SP.SPEAKER: Lig.
SP.P: I haue another, but a worse; I am asham'd, it is a businesse.—

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: You serue a worthy person, and a stranger I am sure you are; you may imploy mee if you please, without your purse, such Office should euer be their owne rewards.

SP.SPEAKER: Lig.
SP.P: I am bound to your noblenesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.L: I may haue neede of you, and then this curtesie,
If it be any, is not ill bestowed:
But may I ciuilly desire the rest?
I shall not be a hurter, if no helper.

SP.SPEAKER: Lig.
SP.L: Sir, you shall know I haue lost a foolish daughter,
And with her all my patience; pilferd away,
By a meane Captaine of your Kings.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.L: Stay there Sir:
If he haue reacht the noble worth of Captaine,
He may well claime a worthy gentlewoman,
Though shee were yours, and noble.

SP.SPEAKER: Lig.
SP.L: I grant all that too: but this wretched fellow
Reaches no further then the emptie name,
That serues to feede him; were he valiant,
Or had but in him any noble nature,
That might hereafter promise him a good man;
My carcs were something lighter, and my graue
A span yet from me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.L: I confesse such fellowes
Be in all royall Campes, and haue, and must be
To make the of coward more detested
In the meane Souldier, that with such a foyle
Sets of much valour: By description
I should now guesse him to you. It was Bessus,
I dare almost with confidence pronounce it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lig.
SP.P: Tis such a scuruy name as Bessus, and now I thinke tis hee.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.L: Captaine, doe you call him?
Beleeue me Sir, you haue a miserie
Too mighty for your age: A pox vpon him,
You a valiant fellow for all this.

SP.SPEAKER: Lig.
SP.L: My daughter is a Whore,
I feele it now too sencible; yet I will see her,
Discharge my selfe of being Father to her,
And then backe to my Countrie, and there die;
Farewell Captaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: Farewell Sir, farewell, commend me to the Gentle∣woman I pria.
How now Captaine, beare vp man.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.L: Gentlemen ath'sword your hands once more, I haue Beene kickt againe, but the foolish fellow is penitent,
Has ask't me mercy, and my honor's safe.
VVe knew that, or the foolish fellow had better a kick't His Grandsire.
Confirme, confirme I pray.

SP.P: There be our hands againe.

SP.L: Now let him come, and say he was not sorry,
And he sleepes for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.L: Alas good ignorant old man, let him goe,
Let him goe, these courses will vndoe him.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: My Lord your authoritie is good, and I am glad it is so, for my confent would neuer hinder you from seeing your owne King. I am a Minister, but not a gouernour of this state; yonder is your King, Ile leaue you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lig.
SP.L: There he is indeed,
And with him my disloyall childe.

SP.SPEAKER: Tig.
SP.L: I doe perceiue my fault so much, that yet
Me thinkes thou shouldst not haue forgiuen me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lig.
SP.P: Health to your Maiestie.

SP.SPEAKER: Tig.
SP.P: VVhat? good Ligones, welcome; what businesse brought thee hether?

SP.SPEAKER: Lig.
SP.L: Seuerall Businesses.
My publique businesse will appeare by this:
I haue a message to deliuer, which
If it please you so to authorise, is
An embassage from the Armenian state;
Vnto Arbaces for your libertie▪
The offer's there set downe, please you to read it.

SP.SPEAKER: Tig.
SP.L: There is no alteration happened
Since I came thence?

SP.SPEAKER: Lig.
SP.P: None Sir, all is as it was.

SP.SPEAKER: Tig.
SP.P: And all our friends are well.

SP.SPEAKER: Lig.
SP.P: All verie well.

SP.SPEAKER: Spa.
SP.L: Though I haue done nothing but what was good,
I dare not see my Father: It was fault
Enough not to acquaint him with that good.

SP.SPEAKER: Lig.
SP.P: Madam I should haue seene you.

SP.SPEAKER: Spa.
SP.P: O good Sir forgiue me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lig.
SP.P: Forgiue you, why I am no kin to you, am I?

SP.SPEAKER: Spa.
SP.L: Should it be measur'd by my meane deserts,
Indeed you are not.

SP.SPEAKER: Lig.
SP.L: Thou couldst prate vnhappily
Ere thou couldst goe, would thou couldst doe as well.
And how does your custome hold out here.

SP.SPEAKER: Spa.
SP.P: Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lig.
SP.P: Are you in priuate still, or how?

SP.SPEAKER: Spa.
SP.P: What doe you meane?

SP.SPEAKER: Lig
SP.P: Doe you take money? are you come to sell sinne yet? perhaps I can helpe you to liberall Clients: or has not the King cast you off yet? O thou vild creature, whose best com∣mendation is, that thou art a young VVhore. I would thy Mother had liu'd to see this: or rather would I had dyed ere I had seene it: why did'st not make me acquainted when thou were first resolu'd to be a Whoe? I would haue seene thy hot lust satisfied more priuately. I would haue kept a dancer, and a whole consort of Musitions in mine owne house, onely to fiddle thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Spa.
SP.P: Sir I was neuer whore.

SP.SPEAKER: Lig.
SP.P: If thou couldst not say so much for thy selfe thou shouldst be Carted.

SP.SPEAKER: Tig.
SP.L: Ligones I haue read it, and like it,
You shall deliuer it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lig.
SP.P: Well Sir I will: but I haue priuate busines with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Tig.
SP.P: Speake, what ist?

SP.SPEAKER: Lig.
SP.L: How has my age deseru'd so ill of you,
That you can picke no strumpets in the Land,
But out of my breed.

SP.SPEAKER: Tig.
SP.P: Strumpets good Ligones?

SP.SPEAKER: Lig.
SP.L: Yes, and I wish to haue you know, I scorne
To get a Whore for any Prince aliue,
And yet scorne will not helpe me thinkes: My daughter
Might haue beene spar'd, there were enough beside.

SP.SPEAKER: Tig.
SP.L: May I not prosper, but Shee's innocent
As morning light for me, and I dare sweare
For all the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Lig.
SP.L: Why is she with you then?
Can she waite on you better then your men,
Has she a gift in plucking off your stockings,
Can she make Cawdles well, or cut your Cornes,
VVhy doe you keepe her with you? For your Queene
I know you doe contemne her, so should I
And euery Subiect else thinke much at it.

SP.SPEAKER: Tig.
SP.L: et vm thinke much, but tis more firme then earth
Thou seest thy Queene there.

SP.SPEAKER: Lig.
SP.L: Then haue I made a faire hand, I cald her Whore,
If I shall speake now as her Father, I cannot of use
But greatly rejoyce that she shall be a Queene: but if
I should speake to you as a Statesman shee were more fit
To be your VVhore.

SP.SPEAKER: Tig.
SP.L: Get you about your businesse to Arbaces,
Now you talke idlie.

SP.SPEAKER: Lig.
SP.L: Yes Sir, I will goe.
And shall she be a Queeue, she had more wit
Then her old Father when she ranne away:
Shall shee be a Queene, now by my troth tis fine,
He dance out of all measure at her wedding:
Shall I not Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Tigr.
SP.P: Yes marrie shalt thou.

SP.SPEAKER: Lig.
SP.L: I'e make these witherd Kexes beare my bodie
Two hrest gether aboue ground.

SP.SPEAKER: Tigr.
SP.P: Nay, goe▪ my businesse requires haste.

SP.SPEAKER: Lig.
SP.P: Good God preserue you, you are an excellent King.

SP.SPEAKER: Spa.
SP.P: Farewell good Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Lig.
SP.L: Farewell sweete vertuous Daughter;
Ineuer was so Joyfull in my life,
That I remember: shall shee be a Queene?
Now I perceiue a man may weepe for ioy,
I had thought they had lied that said so.

SP.SPEAKER: Tig.
SP.L: Come my deare loue.

SP.SPEAKER: Spa.
SP.L: But you may see another
May alter that againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Tigr.
SP.L: Vrge it no more;
I haue made vp a new strong constancie,
Not to be shooke with eyes; I know I haue
The passions of a man, but if I meete
With any subiect that shall hold my eyes
More firmely then is fit; Ile thinke of thee,
And runne away from it: let that suffice.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: Three gentlemen without to speake with me?

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.P: Yes Sir. Bac. Let them come in.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.P: They are enterd Sir already.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: Now fellowes, your busines, are these the Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.P: My Lord I haue made bold to bring these Gentlemen my Friends ath'sword along with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: I am afraid youle fight then.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.L: My good Lord I will not, your Lordship is mistaken,
Feare not Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.L: Sir I am sorrie fort.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: I can aske no more in honor, Gentlemen you heare my Lord is sorrie:

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: Not that I haue beaten you, but beaten one that will be beaten: one whose dull bodie will require launcing: As surfeits doe the diet, spring and full. Stock-fish? Now to your swordmen, what come they for good Captaine

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: It seemes your Lordship has forgot my name.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: No nor your nature neither, though they are things fitter I confesse for any thing, then my remembrance, or anie honest mans, what shall these billets doe, be pilde vp in my VVood-yard?

SP.SPEAKER: Bes
SP.P: Your Lordship holds your mirth still, God continue it: but for these Gentlemen they come.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: To sweare you are a Coward, spare your Booke, I doe beleeue it.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: Your Lordship still drawes wide, they come to vouch vnder their valiant hands, I am no Coward.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: That would be a shew indeed worth seeing: sirra be wise and take money for this motion, trauell with it, and where the name of Bessus has been knowne, or a good Cow∣ard stirring, twill yeeld more then a tilting. This will proue more beneficiall to you, if you be thriftie, then your Captaineship, and more naturall; Men of most valiant hands is this true?

SP.L: It is so most renowned,
Tis somewhat strange.

SP.P: Lord, it is strange, yet true; wee haue examined from your Lordships foote there to this mans head, the nature of the beatings; and we doe find his honour is come off cleane, and sufficient: This as our swords shall helpe vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: You are much bound to your bilbow-men, I am glad you are straight again Captaine▪ twere good you would thinke some way to gratifie them, they haue vndergone a la∣bour for you Bessus, would haue puzzeld Hercules, with all his valour.
Your Lordship must vnderstand we are no men ath' Law, that take pay for our opinions: it is sufficient wee haue cleer'd our friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: Yet here is something due, which I as toucht in con∣science will discharge Captaine; Ile pay this rent for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.P: Spare your selfe my good Lord; my braue friends aime at nothing but the vertue.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: Thats but a cold discharge Sir for their paines.
O Lord▪ my good Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: Be not so modest, I will giue you something.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: They shall dine with your Lordship, that's sufficient.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: Something in hand the while; ye rogues, ye apple∣squiers: doe you come hether with your botled valour, your windle frothe, to limit out my beatings.
I doe beseech your Lordship.
O good Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac:
SP.P: Sfoote, what a many of beaten slaues are here? get me a cudgell sirra, and a tough one.
More of your foot, I doe beseech your Lordship.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: You shall, you shall dog, and your fellow beagle.
A this side good my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: Off with your swords, for if you hurt my foote, Ile haue you fleade you rascals.
Mines off my Lord.
I beseech your Lordship stay a little, my strap's tied to my codpiece point: Now when you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: Captaine, these are your valiant friends, you long for a little too?

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.P: I am verie well, I humblie thanke your Lordship.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: Whats that in your pocket slaue, my key you mung∣rell? thy buttocks cannot be so hard, out with't quicklie.
Here tis Sir, a small piece of Artillerie, that a gentle∣man a deare friend of your Lordships sent me with to get it mended Sir; for if you marke, the nose is somewhat loose.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: A friend of mine you rascall, I was neuer wearier of doing nothing, then kicking these two foote-bals.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.P: Heres a good cudgell Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: It comes too late; I am wearie, prethee doe thou beate vm.
My Lord this is foule play ifaith, to put a fresh man v∣pon vs; Men are but men.

SP.SPEAKER: Bac.
SP.P: That it shall saue your bones, vp with your rotten regiment, and be gone; I had rather thresh, then be bound to kicke these raskals, till they cride hold: Bessus you may put your hand to them now, and then you are quit. Farewell, as you like this, pray visit mee againe, twill keepe me in good breath.
Has a diuellish hard foote, I neuer felt the like.
Nor I, and yet Ime sure I ha felt a hundred.
If he kicke thus ith dog-daies, he will be drie founderd: what cure now Captaine, besides oyle of bayes?

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.P: Why well enough I warrant you, you can goe.
Yes, God be thanked; but I feele a shrewd ach, sure he has sprang my huckle bone.
I ha loft a haunch.

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.P: A little butter friend, a little butter▪ butter and parse∣lie is a soueraigne matter: probatum est.
Captaine, we must request your hands now to our ho∣nours.

SP.SPEAKER: Bess.
SP.P: Yes marrie shall ye, and then let all the world come, we are valiant to our selues, and theres an end:
Nay, then we must be valiant; O my ribbes.
O my small guts, a plague vpon these sharpe toe'd shooes, they are murderers.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Arbaces with his Sword drawne.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: It is resolu'd, I bore it whilst I could,
I can no more, Hell open all thy gates,
And I will thorough them; if they be shut,
Ile batter vm, but I will find the place
VVhere the most damn'd haue dwelling; ere I end,
Amongst them all they shall not haue a sinne,
But I may call it mine: I must beginne
VVith murder of my friend, and so goe on
To an incestuous rauishing, and end
My life and sinnes with a forbidden blow
Vpon my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Mardo.
SP.L: What Tragedie is nere?
That hand was neuer wont to draw a Sword,
But it cride dead to something:

SP.SPEAKER: Arb. Mar.
SP.P: haue you bid Gobrius come?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: How doe you Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: vvell, is he comming?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.L: vvhy Sir are you thus?
why does your hand proclaime a lawlesse warre
Against your selfe?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Thou answerest me one question with another,
Is Gobrius comming?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Sir he is.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Tis well.
I can forbeare your questions then, be gone Sir, I haue markt.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Marke lesse, it troubles you and me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: You are more variable then you were.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: It may be so.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.L: To day no Hermit could be humblier
Then you were to vs all.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: And what of this?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.L: And now you take new rage into your eies,
As you would looke vs all out of the Land.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: I doe confesse it, will that satisfie,
I prethee get thee gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Sir I will speake.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Will ye?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.L: It is my dutie,
I feare you will kill your selfe: I am a subiect,
And you shall doe me wrong in't: tis my cause,
And I may speake.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Thou art not traind in sinne,
It seemes Mardonius: kill my selfe, by heauen
I will not doe it yet; and when I will,
Ile tell thee then: I shall be such a creature,
That thou wilt giue me leaue without a word.
There is a method in mans wickednesse,
It growes vp by degrees; I am not come
So high as killing of my selfe, there are
A hundred thousand sinnes twixt me and it,
Which I must doe, I shall come toot at last;
But take my oath not now, be satisfied,
And get thee hence.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I am sorrie tis so ill.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Be sorrie then,
True sorrow is alone, grieue by thy selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.L: I pray you let mee see your sword put vp
Before I goe; Ile leaue you then.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Why so?
What follie is this in thee? is it not
As apt to mischiefe as it was before?
Can I not reach it thinkest thou? these are toyes
For children to be pleas'd with, and not men;
Now I am safe you thinke: I would the booke
Of Fate were here, my sword is not so sure,
But I should get it out, and mangle that
That all the destinies should quite forget
Their fix't decrees, and hast to make vs new
Farre other Fortunes, mine could not be worse,
Wilt thou now leaue me?

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.L: God put into your bosome temperate thoughts,
Ile leaue you though I feare.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Goe, thou art honest,
Why should the hastie errors of my youth
Be so vnpardonable, to draw a sinne
Helpelesse vpon me?

SP.SPEAKER: Gob
SP.P: There is the King, now it is ripe.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Draw neere thou guiltie man,
That art the author of the loathedst crime
Fiue ages haue brought forth, and heare me speake
Curses incurable, and all the euils
Mans bdie or his spirit can receiue
Be with thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.P: VVhy Sir doe you curse me thus?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: VVhy doe I curse thee, if there be a man
Subtill in curses, that exceedes the rest,
His worst wish on thee. Thou hast broke my hart.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.L: How Sir? Haue I preseru'd you from a childe,
From all the arrowes, malice or ambition
Could shoot at you, and haue I this for pay?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Tis true thou didst preserue me, and in that
VVert crueiler then hardned murderers
Of Infants and their mothers; thou didst saue me
Onely till thou hadst studdied out a way
How to destroy me cunningly thy selfe:
This was a curious way of torturing.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.P: What doe you meane?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Thou knowst the euils thou hast done to me,
Dost thou remember all those witching letters
Thou sentst vnto me to Armenia,
Fild with the praise of my beloued Sister,
Where thou extolst her beautie; what had I
To doe with that, what could her beautie be
To me, and thou didst write how well shee lou'd me,
Doest thou remember this: so that I doated
Something before I saw her.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.P: This is true.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Is it, and when I was returnd thou knowst
Thou didst pursue it, till thou woundst mee into
Such a strange, and vnbeleeu'd affection,
As good men cannot thinke on.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.P: This I grant, I thinke I was the cause.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: VVert thou▪ Nay more, I thinke thou meantst it.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.L: Sir I haue a lie
As I loue God and honestie, I did:
It was my meaning.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Be thine owne sad Iudge,
A further condemnation will not need:
Prepare thy selfe to die.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.L: VVhy Sir to die?
VVhy wouldst thou liue, was euer yet offendor
So impudent, that had a thought of mercy
After confession of a crime like this?
Get out I cannot, where thou hurlst me in,
But I can take reuenge, that's all the sweetnesse
Left for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.P: Now is the time, heare me but speake.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: No, yet I will be farre more mercifull
Then thou wert to me; thou didst steale into me,
And neuer gauest me warning: so much time
As I giue thee now, had preuented thee
For euer. Notwithstanding all thy sinnes,
If thou hast hope, that there is yet a prayer
To saue thee, turne, and speake it to your selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.P: Sir, you shall know your sinnes before you doe vm If you kill me.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: I will not stay then.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.P: Know you kill your Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: How?

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.P: You kill your Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: My Father? though I know it for a lie
Made out of feare to saue thy stained life:
The verie reuerence of the word comes crosse me,
And ties mine arme downe.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.L: I will tell you that shall heighten you againe, I am thy
Father, I charge thee heare me.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: If it should be so,
As tis most false, and that I should be sound
A bastard issue, the dispised fruite
Of lawlesse lust, I should no more admire
All my wilde passions: but another truth
Shall be wrung from thee: If I could come by
The spirit of paine, it should be powr'd on thee,
Till thou allowest thy selfe more full of lies
Then he that teaches thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Arane.
SP.L: Turne thee about,
I come to speake to thee thou wicked man,
Heare me thou Tyrant.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: I will turne to thee,
Heare me thou Strumpet: I haue blotted out
The name of mother, as thou hast thy shame.

SP.SPEAKER: Ara.
SP.L: My shame, thou hast lesse shame then any thing:
Why dost thou keepe my daughter in a prison?
Why dost thou call her Sister, and doe this?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Cease thou strange impudence, and answere quickly,
If thou contemn'st me, this will aske an answere,
And haue it.

SP.SPEAKER: Ara.
SP.P: Helpe me gentle Gobrius.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Guilt dare not helpe guilt, though they grow together
In doing ill, yet at the punishment
They seuer, and each flies the noyse of other,
Thinke not of helpe, answere.

SP.SPEAKER: Ara.
SP.P: I will, to what?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: To such a thing as if it be a truth,
Thinke what a creature thou hast made thy selfe,
That didst not shame to doe, what I must blush
Onely to aske thee: tell me who I am,
Whose sonne I am, without all circumstance;
Be thou as hastie, as my Sword will be
If thou refusest.

SP.SPEAKER: Ara.
SP.P: VVhy you are his sonne.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: His sonne?
Sweare, sweare, thou worse then woman damn'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Ara.
SP.P: By all thats good you are.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Then art thou all that euer was knowne bad. Now is
The cause of all my strange misfortunes come to light:
What reuerence expects thou from a childe
To bring forth which thou hast offended Heauen,
Thy husband and the Land: Adulterous witch
I know now why thou wouldst haue poyson'd me,
I was thy lust which thou wouldst haue forgot:
Thou wicked mother of my sinnes, and me,
Shew me the way to the inheritance
I haue by thee: which is a spacious world
Of impious acts, that I may soone possesse it:
Plagues rott thee, as thou liu'st, and such diseases
As vse to pay lust, recompence thy deed.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.P: You doe not know why you curse thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Too well:
You are a paire of Vipers, and behold
The Serpent you haue got; there is no beast
But if he knew, it has a pedigree
As braue as mine, for they haue more discents,
And I am euery way as beastly got,
As farre without the compasse of a law,
As they.

SP.SPEAKER: Ara.
SP.L: You spend your rage, and words in vaine,
And raile vpon a guesse: heare vs a little.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: No I will neuer heare, but talke away
My breath, and die.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.P: VVhy but you are no Baftard.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Howe's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Ara.
SP.P: Nor childe of mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Still you goe on in wonders to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.P: Pray be more patient, I may bring comfort to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: I will kneele,
And heare with the obedience of a childe;
Good Father speake, I doe acknowledge you,
So you bring comfort.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.L: First know our last King your supposed Father
VVas olde and feeble when he marryed her,
And almost all the Land as shee past hope
Of issue from him.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Therefore shee tooke leaue
To play the whoore, because the King was old:
Is this the comfort?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: vvhat will you find out
To giue me satisfaction, when you find
How you haue iniur'd me: let fire consume mee,
If euer I were whore.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.L: Forbeare these starts,
Or I will leaue you wedded to despaire,
As you are now: if you can find a temper,
My breath shall be a pleasant westerne wind,
That cooles, and blastes not.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Bring it out good Father,
Ile lie, and listen here as reuerentlie
As to an Angell: If I breathe too loude,
Tell me; for I would be as still as night.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.L: Our King I say was old, and this our Queene
Desired to bring an heire; but yet her husband
Shee thought was past it, and to be dishonest
I thinke shee would not; if shee would haue beene,
The truth is, shee was watcht so narrowlie,
And had so slender opportunitie,
Shee hardly could haue beene: But yet her cunning
Found out this way; shee fain'd her selfe with child,
And postes were sent in haste throughout the Land,
And God was humbly thankt in euery Church,
That so had blest the Queen, and prayers were made
For her safe going, and deliuerie:
Shee fain'd now to grow bigger, and perceiu'd
This hope of issue made her feard, and brought
A farre more large respect from euerie man,
And saw her power increase, and was resolu'd,
Since shee belieu'd shee could not haue't indeede;
At least shee would be thought to haue a child.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Doe I not heare it well; nay, I will make
No noise at all; but pray you to the point,
Quicke as you can.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob
SP.L: Now when the time was full,
Shee should be brought abed; I had a sonne
Borne, which was you: This the Queene hearing of,
Mou'd me to let her haue you, and such reasons
Shee shewed me as shee knew would tie
My secresie: shee sware you should be King;
And o be short, did deliue you
Vnto her, and pretended you we e dead;
And in mine owne house kept a Funerall,
And had an emprie coffin put in earth:
That night the Queene fain'd hastilie to labour,
And by a paire of women of her owne.
VVhich shee had charm'd, shee made the world belieue
Shee was deliuer'd of you: you grew vp
As the Kings sonne▪ till you were sixe yeere olde;
Then did the King die, and did leaue to me
Protection of the Realme; and contrarie
To his owne expectation, left this Queene
Truly with childe indeed of the faire Princesse
Panthaea: Then shee could haue torne her heire,
And did alone to me yet durst not speake
In publie; for shee knew shee should be found
A Traytor, and her talke would haue beene thought
Madnesse or any thing rather then truth:
This was the onely cause why shee did seeke
To poyson you, and I to keepe you safe:
And this the reason why I sought to kindle
Some sparke of loue in you to faire Panthaea,
That shee might get part of her right agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: And haue you made an end now, is this all?
If not, I will be still till I am aged,
Till all my heires are siluer.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob
SP.P: This is all.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: And is it true say you Maddam?

SP.SPEAKER: Ara.
SP.P: Yes God knowes it is most true.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Panthaea t en is not my Sister. Gob No.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: But can you proue this?
If you will giue consent: else who dare goe about it.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Giue consent?
VVhy I will haue them all that know it rackt
To get this from vm: All that waites without
Come in, what ere you be come in, and be
Partakers of my Ioy: O you are welcome.
Mardonius the best newes, nay, draw no neerer
They all shall heare it: I am found no King.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Is that so good newes?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Yes, the happiest newes that ere was heard.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.L: Indeed twere well for you,
If you might be a little lesse obey'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: On, call the Queene.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Why she is there.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: The Queene Mardonius, Panthaea is the Queene,
And I am plaine Arbaces, goe some one,
She is in Gobrius house; since I saw you
There are a thousand things deliuerd to me
You little dreame of.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.L: So it should seeme: My Lord,
VVhat furi's this.

SP.SPEAKER: Gob.
SP.L: Beleeue me tis no fury,
All that he sayes is truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar
SP.P: Tis verie strange.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb
SP.L: Why doe you keepe your hats off Gentlemen,
Is it to me? good faith it must not be:
I cannot now command you, but I pray you
For the respect you bare me, when you tooke
Me for your King, each man clap on his hat at my desire.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.L: We will: but you are not found
So meane a man, but that you may be couer'd
As well as we, may you not?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: O not here,
You may but not I, for here is my Father in presence,

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: VVhere?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Why there O the whole storie
Would be a wildernesse to loose thy selfe
For euer; O pardon me deare Father,
For all the idle, and vnreuerent words
That I haue spoke in idle moodes to you:
I am Arbaces, we all fellow subiects,
Nor is the Queene Panthaa now my Sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: Why if you remember fellow subiect Arbaces, I tolde you once she was not your sister, I say she look't nothing like you.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: I thinke you did good Captaine Bessus.

SP.SPEAKER: Bes.
SP.P: Here will arise another question now amongst the Swordmen, whether I be to call him to account for beating me, now he's prou'd no King.

SP.SPEAKER: Ma.
SP.L: Sir, heres Ligones
The Agent for the Armenian King.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Where is he, I know your businesse good Ligones,

SP.SPEAKER: Lig.
SP.P: VVe must haue our King againe, and will.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: I knew that was your businesse, you shall haue
Your King againe, and haue him so againe
As neuer King was had. Goe one of you
And bid Bacurius bring Tigranes hither,
And bring the Ladie with him, that Panthaea
The Queene Panthaa sent me word this morning
VVas braue Tigranes mistresse.

SP.SPEAKER: Lig.
SP.P: Tis Spaconia.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: I, I, Spaconia.

SP.SPEAKER: Lig.
SP.P: She is my daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Shee is so, I could now tell any thing
I neuer heard; your King shall goe so home
As neuer man went.

SP.SPEAKER: Ma.
SP.L: Shall he goe on's head?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: He shall haue Chariots easier then ayre
That I will haue inuented; and nere thinke
He shall pay any ransome; and thy selfe
That art the Messenger shall ride before him
On a Horse cut out of an entire Diamond,
That shall be made to goe with golden wheeles,
I know not how yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Lig.
SP.L: VVhy I shall be made
For euer, they belied this King with vs
And savd he was vnkind.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb
SP.L: And then thy daughter,
She shall haue some strange thinke, wele haue the kingdome
Sold vtterly, and put into a toy.
Which she shall weare about her carelesly
Some where or other.
See the vertuous Queene.
Behold the humblest subiect that you haue
Kneele here before you.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: VVhy kneele you
To me that am your vassall?

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Grant me one request.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: Alas, what can I grant you?
VVhat I can I will.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: That you will please to marry me,
If I can proue it lawfull.

SP.SPEAKER: Pan.
SP.L: Is that all?
More willingly, then I would draw this ayre.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.P: Ile kisse this hand in earnest.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.L: Sir, Tigranes is comming though he made it strange
To see the Princesse any more.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: The Queene,
Thou meanest: O my Tigranes pardon me,
Tread on my necke I freely offer it,
And if thou beest so giuen; take reuenge,
For I haue iniur'd thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Tig.
SP.L: No, I forgiue,
And rejoice more that you haue found repentance,
Then I my libertie.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Maist thou be happie
In thy faire choice; for thou art temperate:
You owe no ransome to the state, know that;
I haue a thousand ioyes to tell you of,
vvhich yet I dare not vter, till I pay
My thankes to Heauen for vm: will you goe
vvith me, and l e me; pray you doe.

SP.SPEAKER: Tig.
SP.P: I will.

SP.SPEAKER: Arb.
SP.L: Take then your faire one with you, and your Queene
Of goodnesse, and of vs; O giue me leaue
To take your arme in mine: Come euery one
That takes delight in goodnesse, helpe to sing
Loude thankes for me, that I am prou'd no King.
